I bought this book almost two years ago after reading Haruki Murakami's Kafka on the Shore (4 stars) and The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle (4 stars). I liked those novels a lot so I purchased and read most of his other books right away like Sputnik Sweetheart (3 stars), After Dark (4 stars), Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman (3 stars), After the Quake (1 star - this used to be 3 stars until I saw my brother's review) and even his biography, Haruki Murakami and the Music of Words (3 stars). A couple of months back, I read his most challenging-to-read novel, Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World and it was just okay, 2 stars. I think the more books of him I read, the less I like him. Those first 3 books of him that I read were really good. His style of writing was very different and his imagination was overwhelmingly beautiful. However, as I read his other books, even though I gave enough distance in between two books, I got tired of his style so the stories just felt ordinary. He had the tendency to re-use his materials: characters, plot, conflict, setting, etc. There were just obvious similarities that were just hard to ignore. This is my 8th book by Haruki Murakami and this makes him one of my two most-read authors. He's now tied with Bob Ong, a Filipino writer whose works I read not because I like him but because many young Filipinos adore him and keep on talking about his books in our group here in Goodreads.What I Talk About When I Talk About Running is his only memoir (so far). My first non-fiction of him. It is about his hobby, running that he tried to compare with writing a novel. The memoir tells so little about his life like how he became a novelist and only mentioned his wife in a couple of anecdotes. The narration was fragmentary as he said in the epilogue that it took him four years to write his thoughts and so he just collated everything and presto, this book. He used so many words but for me his main message was: Even if I am already old, I run because I want to keep fit so I can continue writing great novels. It was as simple as that. The thing is we all do that. We take care of ourselves so that we can continue earning and provide for our family. So, the book came to me as bragging, self-serving, presumptuous and stating the obvious. Haruki Murakami was born in 1949 so he was 51-55 y/o (this year he is now 62) when he was writing entries to this memoir and he was telling here about his training for triathlon (swimming, biking and running). So when, he was describing here that he was experiencing all sorts of pains and injuries while barely mentioning about getting old and seeing doctors, my brain was shouting: 
"You are already old, stop being hard on yourself!"
. Bottomline, I think he was trying to hold back the hands of time. He was a late-bloomer as he only thought of writing when he was 30. He was not comfortable about getting old so he wanted to prove that he could still compete with much younger men. I am so sorry for him. It's just so pathetic. But still, it was hard for me to give this a lone star (I didn't like it!). Haruki Murakami's narration was still as beautiful as ever.

Everything I learned about writing, I learned by running...so writes Haruki Murakami. This was the second time I read this book, but I read it three different ways this time. I bought a used Japanese edition. I read it paragraph by paragraph alongside the English edition. I read it by running. If I were truly to understand this bookâ€™s meaning this time around, I would need to run. I set a timer for 20 minutes and ran every other day. That doesnâ€™t sound like a long time, especially when you consider that Murakami ran an ultramarathon, but for me it hurt like hell. I proofread my novel-in-progress in a similar manner to the way I ran. I set a 10 minute timer and proofread the book in two 10-minute stretches every day. What am I training for? Iâ€™m training for the marathon that is my life. I want to be thinner. I want to be more disciplined. And I want a novel that is long and lean and built to last like a marathon runner. Perhaps the only way to do that is to run every day...to read every day...to proofread every day...to revise every day...but most importantly to hurt every day.

Most runners run not because they want to live longer, but because they want to live life to the fullest. If youâ€™re going to while away the years, itâ€™s far better to live them with clear goals and fully alive than in a fog, and I believe running helps you do that. Exerting yourself to the fullest within your individual limits; thatâ€™s the essence of running, and a metaphor for life - and for me, for writing as well. I believe many runners would agree.And wholeheartedly so! While quite a few family members and friends of mine have read Murakamiâ€™s novels, I have not gotten onto that train yet. This memoir, however, intrigued me and given that it is relatively short I felt that it will not take me away from my planned reading too much. The book in itself is very simple. Sometimes the writing comes across as almost elementary for a novelist of his renown, but it could be due to the translation or because it is written like journal entries, albeit with more eloquence than most of us can fashion. As a novelist who runs, he equated the challenges of writing closely to that of running and how the discipline of being a long-distance runner translated across to that of writing. I am not a writer but little did I realize how much Iâ€™d identify with Murakamiâ€™s memoir about running, writing and to a lesser extent, ageing. And it inspires me enough to round out my review of his book by facing the question of â€œWhat running means to me?â€And it is not a simple answer. By some sheer coincidence, I started running at the same age that Murakami did, i.e. thirty-three. Although I was no couch potato, running was not something that Iâ€™d enjoyed. Something changed, however, when I decided to participate in my first ever 10km race in Singaporeâ€™s flagship event which was headline sponsored by the bank I worked for (still am working for actually). There is a very strong sense of community which is almost tribal amongst runners. The bonds that one forms with fellow runners whom you may not know transcend all boundaries when you are out there giving it your all. There are tonnes of stories and viral videos of runners helping strangers who are struggling to the finish line. We even see this sometimes in a competitive pro event. Personally, the closest friends that I have to-date are those whom I have met or fostered friendships through running. On an even more personal level, the contest of running is all within oneself. Thereâ€™s no one across the net from you that you are trying to beat (I used to play tennis before I started running). The only one you are trying to beat is yourself and your own perceived limits, both physical and mental. Each and every year since Iâ€™ve started running, Iâ€™ve set a personal goal for myself - from running a 10k to a half marathon and eventually a full marathon. Then I started on triathlons as well (just like Murakami too), from a mini one to sprint and then the Olympic distance. After that, my goal is to beat my PB (ie. personal best) for the same distances that I have achieved. And when people ask me why I keep setting myself these goals every year, I tell them that most of us who work as an employee, the work that we do seldom make enough of a difference that you can claim a legacy that is yours. However, these personal goals, if I do meet them, are mine and mine alone. I am a barely mediocre runner and this is not me trying to be modest. But I do what I want to do and it's my personal achievement within the challenged limits of my body and mind. And that is what I talk about when I talk about running.

Oh Murakami. You know how to make me happy in the simplest of ways.I'm not a runner. I enjoy running now and again but I wouldn't term myself a runner. And ordinarily I wouldn't pick up books that are classified in the 'sport - non-fiction' genre - I didn't even know that was a genre but hey, that's what it is on the back of my copy! But Murakami doesn't just write about running, he also talks about writing and his life and I find him endlessly fascinating even when he is talking about what could be a very bland subject.I loved charting Murakami's progress towards his various marathons, his description of running an ultra-marathon, and also the variety of places he had travelled to both to run and write. He made me want to pick up a pen and start writing again. He made me want to lace up my running shoes and hit the pavement, no matter how unfit I currently am. He made me want to appreciate the little things and develop my own life routines. He made me not feel bad about sometimes just being happy to be on my own.This isn't a perfect book by any means, but it's what I needed at the time, and I would recommend it to anyone who has an interest in either running, writing, or just memoir in general.

Î¤Î¿ Ï€ÏÏ‚ Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Î¼ÎµÏ„ÏÏ€Î¹Î¶Îµ Ï„Î¿ Ï„ÏÎ­Î¾Î¹Î¼Î¿, Ï„Î¿ Ï€ÏÏ‚ Ï„Î¿ ÎµÎ½Î­Ï„Î±ÏƒÏƒÎµ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î¶Ï‰Î® Ï„Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î´Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¬ Ï„Î¿Ï…, ÎºÎ±Î¸ÏÏ‚ ÎµÎ¯Î½Î±Î¹ ÏƒÎºÎ­ÏˆÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î¹Î´Î­ÎµÏ‚ Ï€Î¿Ï… Î¼Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¿ÏÎ½ Î½Î± ÎµÏ†Î±ÏÎ¼Î¿ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎ½ ÎºÎ¹ Î±Î»Î»Î¿Ï. Î•Î³Ï ÎºÎ¬Ï€Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ¬Ï€Î¿Ï… Ï„Î±Ï…Ï„Î¹Î¶ÏŒÎ¼Î¿Ï…Î½ ÏƒÎ¯Î³Î¿Ï…ÏÎ± Ï€Î¬Î½Ï„Ï‰Ï‚!When I tell people I run every day, some are quite impressed. "You really must have a strong will," they sometimes tell me. Of course, it's nice to be praised like this. A lot better than being disparaged, that's for sure. But I don't think it's merely willpower that makes you able to do something. The world isn't that simple. To tell the truth, I don't even think there's that much correlation between my running every day and whether or not I have a strong will. I think I've been able to run for more than twenty years for a simple reason: It suits me.

Recommended by Paul :)Ran 14k yesterday without stopping once! I didn't know this was possible/ healthy. Best run I ever did done. And I would do again today if I wasn't achey :DThis was thanks to Murakami's running mania. He also gave me permission not to think about anything in particular and listen to mediocre music. Before, my head sounded like that anxious stream that visits you at night if you've forgotten to place a notepad on your nightstand. But the running is strenuous enough without all that mental exhaustion also.IDK who I'd recommend this to, though- if you come here looking for Murakami, you'll be disappointed. (Omg that other non-fiction of his, Underground, was so tedious!)But now I have hope I'll be one of those weird guys who reaches his prime in his 50s and writes like 100 novels a year by dictating them while running ultramarathons. Like Eddie Izzard.I just need the right pair of heels.

I picked this book as part of my Read Harder Challenge and I liked it despite being repetitive in so many parts. What we have here is a daily memoir of Murakamiâ€™s running and the marathons he participated in. Iâ€™m a fan of Murakamiâ€™s work and this books wasnâ€™t any different.I liked the fact that he put whatever was on his mind, of course I might be wrong but at least it seems like that to me. Heâ€™s written down struggles, mental or physicals that he faced when preparing or even running for a marathon.The concepts he has in this book can apply to different aspects of life. He speaks of running and marathons but I can think of infinite situations that I thought Iâ€™m ready enough to face and pass them but when happened I realized I was wrong. Even sometimes itâ€™s not about how prepared you are but just the simple fact that you donâ€™t have what is needed and you cannot have itâ€¦ itâ€™s just knowing your limits and your potentials.That was my impression of this book.
Finally, Haruki writes about himself! I loved it ğŸ’™
Murakami is one of my favorite authors

This is, I think, the second book I've read about distance running. I am wondering what my fascination with that is, although truly, I've read both because they came up on various lists. I, myself, am a walker. I love to go for long walks in the morning. Running does not as much appeal. You can read why I came to this decision here.In the meantime, you can read the entire review at Smorgasbook

Sono una persona che ha una profonda ed appassionata relazione con il proprio divano: tutte quelle attivitÃ  che comportano della fatica fisica, il sudore, lo spingersi almeno un pochino oltre il proprio punto di massimo sforzo non hanno mai fatto per me; mi sento goffa, mi sento scoppiare il cuore dopo un paio di rampe di scale, la mia costanza e determinazione sono pari a zero. Non impazzisco per Murakami, ho apprezzato qualcosa di suo, ma gli ultimi approcci mi hanno a dire il vero piuttosto irritata.Dunque, verrebbe da chiedersi, a che pro leggere un saggio su un argomento lontanissimo da me scritto da un autore che non adoro? Be', perchÃ© Murakami Ã¨ diventato una sorta di porto sicuro. Non mi fa impazzire, eppure so esattamente cosa aspettarmi dai suoi libri, e leggerlo mi dÃ  un senso di sicurezza: so che nei suoi libri troverÃ² diverse cose che non mi piaceranno, so che mi lamenterÃ² sempre delle stesse cose, ma non posso fare a meno di leggere almeno un Murakami all'anno.E poi c'Ã¨ la corsa. Ebbene, un paio d'anni fa mi sono ritrovata a cercare di andare a vedere una mostra alla Triennale di Milano, senza avere la minima idea che sarei stata bloccata dalle transenne della Stramilano. Mentre me ne stavo lÃ¬ a cercare di raccapezzarmi su come fare per attraversare quella maledetta strada, ho cominciato a guardarmi attorno, ed ho imparato alcune cose: ho imparato che c'Ã¨ gente che partecipa alle corse solo per il gusto di fare pipÃ¬ davanti a chiunque, senza nemmeno cercare di nascondersi, e anzi, sorridendo allegramente a chiunque abbia la fortuna di incrociare il suo sguardo; ho imparato che durante le corse (o forse, spero, Ã¨ solo questa ad avere un problemino di organizzazione) si spreca una grandissima quantitÃ  di acqua e di plastica, perchÃ© lungo il percorso ci sono punti di ristoro pieni di bottigliette d'acqua da cui gli atleti bevono qualche sorso, per poi buttarle come se niente fosse a terra; infine, ho imparato che lungo tutto il percorso di una corsa ci sono persone che non fanno altro che lanciare grida di incoraggiamento ai corridori, a tutti, e ho imparato che ci sono pochissime cose al mondo in grado di commuovermi in maniera cosÃ¬ totale e rapida quanto delle persone che compiono un grande sforzo fisico circondate da altre persone che, incessantemente, le incoraggiano. Ecco, questa valanga di parole per dire che, forse, "L'arte di correre" non Ã¨ poi un libro cosÃ¬ tanto lontano da me. PerchÃ© Murakami parla di corsa, ma non vuole scrivere nÃ© un manuale per corridori principianti, nÃ© un libro che ogni due pagine grida "hey, alza il sedere e scendi in strada a correre!". PerchÃ© Murakami parla di corsa e di scrittura, parla dei suoi libri, lo fa con la voce che ho imparato a riconoscere come familiare, ma senza tutti quegli elementi che mi fanno avvertire come irritante la lettura dei suoi libri."L'arte di correre" Ã¨ un insieme poco organico di ricordi sparsi, aneddoti, riflessioni sulla vita di Murakami, la scrittura e la corsa. Non ha uno scopo preciso, non Ã¨ particolarmente esauriente, ma probabilmente l'ho apprezzato proprio per questo: Murakami si ritaglia del tempo fra i vari impegni giornalieri per liberarsi di pensieri e riflessioni, senza direttive o progetti di organicitÃ , e da questi pensieri sparsi emerge un libro che si puÃ² leggere a spizzichi e bocconi, senza avere un particolare interesse nÃ© per Murakami, nÃ© per la corsa.Mi Ã¨ molto piaciuto, in qualche modo mi ha, posso dir, consolato questo parallelo fra la scrittura di un romanzo e il correre una maratona: per fare entrambe le cose serve concentrazione, serve perseveranza, dedizione, sforzo, esercizio costante; certo una naturale predisposizione serve, ma Ã¨ rincuorante pensare che la concentrazione sia esattamente come un muscolo. Ed Ã¨ terribilmente rincuorante sapere che Ã¨ esistito un uomo che un giorno era un barista sovrappeso che fumava diversi pacchetti di sigarette, ed il giorno dopo Ã¨ riuscito a diventare scrittore di professione e maratoneta. Soprattutto perchÃ© Murakami non si presenta mai come un superuomo, un eroe, qualcuno che stato capace di compiere un gesto straordinario: Murakami resta un uomo con mille difetti, riconosce di essere antipatico a molti, ammette le sue debolezze e i suoi errori, parla del "runner blues" e di tutte le birre ghiacciate che lo hanno tormentato a partire dal trentacinquesimo chilometro.Ãˆ ovvio, dopo questo libro non scriverÃ² certamente un romanzo, nÃ© mi alzerÃ² ogni mattina alle cinque per andare a correre, perÃ² mi resteranno bene impresse nella mente delle immagini piccole ma preziose, come la coda di cavallo bionda di una studentessa di Harvard, la sensazione di non saper respirare mentre tutti attorno si affannano a nuotare, o il gesto semplice di un vecchino a Maratona che toglie un mazzolino di fiori dal loro vaso per porgerli ad un uomo che ha contato i corpi degli animali lungo una statale.

How do you talk about the things that you love, the things that make you who you are?You talk about them like this. Murakami dives into his passion for running and intermingles it with his success as a writer. With this work Murakami manages to hone in on two cross sections of society: writers & athletes. Both people that love to run, and those who love to read, can find value in this work. Even readers that don't enjoy running can gain knowledge from reading this work. This is a work that shows the importance of exercising the mind, body and spirit.What I Talk About When I Talk About Running is a memoir. The writing style is simple and conversational. Murakami wrote many of these chapters as journal entries while training for marathons. It is deeply introspective, and inspires introspection on the part of the reader. There is a lot to be gleaned about the author and ourselves from reading this.Far from being preachy, Murakami simply talks about his own experiences and goals. This is a beneficial work to read if you are looking to make a change and achieve a goal.â€œPeople sometimes sneer at those who run every day, claiming theyâ€™ll go to any length to live longer. But I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s the reason most people run. Most runners run not because they want to live longer, but because they want to live life to the fullest. If youâ€™re going to while away the years, itâ€™s far better to live them with clear goals and fully alive than in a fog, and I believe running helps you do that. Exerting yourself to the fullest within your individual limits: thatâ€™s the essence of running, and a metaphor for lifeâ€”and for me, for writing as well. I believe many runners would agree.â€Despite being nonfiction, there are still signs of Murakami's classic speculative style. Many sentences brought me back to The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, my chosen favorite novel of Murakami's. Even for those fans of Murakami not interested in running and writing can enjoy this story for moments like these.â€œI look up at the sky, wondering if I'll catch a glimpse of kindness there, but I don't. All I see are indifferent summer clouds drifting over the Pacific. And they have nothing to say to me. Clouds are always taciturn. I probably shouldn't be looking up at them. What I should be looking at is inside of me. Like staring down into a deep well. Can I see kindness there? No, all I see is my own nature. My own individual, stubborn, uncooperative often self-centered nature that still doubts itself--that, when troubles occur, tries to find something funny, or something nearly funny, about the situation. I've carried this character around like an old suitcase, down a long, dusty path. I'm not carrying it because I like it. The contents are too heavy, and it looks crummy, fraying in spots. I've carried it with me because there was nothing else I was supposed to carry. Still, I guess I have grown attached to it. As you might expect.â€I also think this work humanizes him. Murakami is popular abroad, but he was HUGELY popular in Japan. There are countless accounts of him being mobbed at airports, harassed on the streets, etc, to the point where he left Japan to live abroad. This work shows another side of Murakami that readers may not see: He's more than just the man behind the page, he's a human with human interests and aspirations outside of authorship.

First book I read from Murakami and it just is unlike anything Iâ€™ve ever read. Loved how it was simply yet beautifully written. As a runner and former triathlete myself I could relate with some of the stories he shared. It made me laugh at times and also reignited my desire to run more consistently again.

(3.5 stars) My timing is about as wrong as it can be when it comes to reading a motivational book about running in the month of November. After all, I live in Scandinavia â€“ not in the darkest corners of it perhaps, but still. As a Danish poet once said, there are 15 months to a year, 3 of which are November, November, November. Trying to sustain a modicum of motivation is thus an effort worthy of Sisyphus and other masochists. When, at regular intervals during the book, Murakami would complain about a spot of rain that prevented him from running, I could but laugh derisively. The book is a memoir of sorts â€“ Murakami himself calls it a memoir â€“ but 9/10 of it is about running, the last 1/10 dealing with writing, triathlon, moving country, collecting records and a sentence or three about his wife. This is a book for people who are either really into running or really into Murakami. Most of the book is written in a chatty, mundane style. Itâ€™s honest but also somewhat repetitive. We hear a lot about his running results, his goals for his next marathon, his decision to supplement his running with triathlons. Some of it is quite fascinating, such as his first marathon â€“ which he ran from Athens to the town of Marathon 42 kilometers away â€“ without it being a proper race but merely because he was writing an article about it and wasnâ€™t prepared to cheat. At the end of this run he finally drinks the beer that heâ€™d been dreaming of during the last 12 kilometers, and although he enjoyed it, it wasnâ€™t as good as heâ€™d expected:Nothing in the world can compare to the fantasies of a person who has lost consciousness.*This paves the way for the extreme focus that Murakami has: his ability to push himself in his running has enabled him to push his limits when it comes to his writing as well (though how is a bit unclear). This is a man who has run 10 kilometers a day for about 25 years. And heâ€™s already decided what he wants written on his tombstone: At least he never walked. Talk about single-mindedness. He got a bit carried away here and there when it came to telling us about how fit he was or about the minutiae of his training. A quote comes to mind:The barrier between healthy confidence and unhealthy conceit is very thin.He stays on the right side of this, but the details became slightly tedious. Then again the book isnâ€™t very long so it was not a major problem, and after all, Iâ€™m not a long distance runner, preferring the shorter (urban) distances (when I run at all, cf. the Scandinavian weather/darkness). He often spices up accounts of his training with philosophizing, which I enjoyed. (I also made a note of the fact that he, at the time of running the New York City marathon (for the 3rd or 4th time, I think), bought new Mizuno running shoes, which â€“ as it happened â€“ were the shoes I used to run in, the first pair of which I bought in New York). He owns up to his life not being spectacular (outside of his writing, I would venture). He imagines - but doesnâ€™t particularly like â€“ the idea of his life made into a movie. The director would say something like: â€˜can we leave out that scene? Itâ€™s not bad but itâ€™s nothing specialâ€™ â€“ Murakamiâ€™s point being that most of our lives are an accumulation of banal events, yet they are meaningful to us. I chuckled at that, while acknowledging the truthfulness of his observation. In sum:Quality of life is about acting/doing and not so much about time, numbers or rank. Murakami talks about his time in a triathlon here, but I would draw (as I suspect he does) a line to our lives in general.Murakami is to make a guest appearance in my town next year, having been awarded the Hans Christian Andersen prize (which Salman Rushdie won last year, J.K. Rowling a few years ago), so I may just have to don my groupie outfit and go seek him out. This book was interesting, but Iâ€™ll look forward to reading more of his quirky prose (the only other book Iâ€™ve read by him so far being Kafka on the Shore).(*All quotes here are translations from the Danish and may not be the exact equivalents of the English quotes, not to mention the original Japanese).

Haruki Murakami is a "writer and runner." As I read this book, I hoped to gain an understanding of why he runs. I prefer to walk and take life at a slower pace and running seems like so much exertion! He writes that most runners run "because they want to live life to the fullest." What I came to understand as I read, is that setting goals for running and reaching those goals provides a framework for living and adds purpose and meaning to life. He explains further, "Exerting yourself to the fullest within your individual limits: that's the essence of running and a metaphor for life - and for me, writing as well."I really enjoyed his thoughts on the changing of the seasons and how they impact runners. He writes that "runners can detect each notch in the the seasonal shift in the feel of the wind against our skin its smell and direction," which I found profound and loved his sensitivity to his natural environment. I especially enjoyed his personal connection with water and his description of the effect of light and wind on the river is lovely.Murakami talks of his personal experience of running by water, "In the midst of this flow, I'm aware of myself as one tiny piece in the gigantic mosaic of nature. I'm just a replaceable natural phenomenon, like the water in the river that flows under the bridge to the sea." I just love that. Narration by Ray Porter is good, his voice is easy on the ears.*Fascinating fact: I just read on LitHub that Haruki Murakami completed his first ultramarathon on June 23rd, 1996, exactly 25 years ago today!

I was so surprised by just how much I liked this short memoir, seeing as I drink, smoke, eat a diet that can be good one day and utter crap the next, and apart from walking haven't broken into a sweat through any sort of exercise for about 10 years. Yet I've always remained slim, and most of my family that I don't see that often think I'm super fit.Ha! If only I told them the truth! . . . It's more like Charles Bukowski in disguise!  I was more exhausted than Murakami by simply reading about his exhaustion! And the funny thing is, it was the running side of this memoir - it's not just all about running, that I found most fascinating. Hats off to anyone who can compete in an ultramarathon: I'd struggle to run to the end of the street . . . unless it was some bastard running off with one of my cats!Murakami made for such great company in the couple of hours it took to read this.

No leÃ­a a Murakami desde "Tokio Blues", que pasÃ³ por mis manos hace varios aÃ±os y que ME ENCANTÃ“, pero luego el autor me saliÃ³ tan en la sopa, que me empezÃ³ a caer en desgracia. La culpa, en todo caso, no fue de Murakami mismo, sino que de la intensidad de su fanaticada, demasiado fiel en cada una de las entregas. Tengo un amigo que hasta se puso de nick de messenger (se me cayÃ³ el carnet, jajaja), el tÃ­tulo de uno de uno de sus libros durante AÃ‘OS, ese de los nÃºmeros (1Q84). SegÃºn Ã©l que era el mejor del mundo... Yo todavÃ­a no me animo a leerlo. Siento que si lo hago terminarÃ© vomitando unicornios de colores.Bueno, ese amigo en realidad era mÃ¡s que un amigo, y no terminÃ³ muy bien la cosa, jejeje. Supongo que eso influyÃ³ tambiÃ©n en mis sentimientos y que la responsabilidad de ese punto en especÃ­fico al final es mÃ­a (Â¡y de Ã©l!).Ahora, volviendo a lo de hoy... me ENCANTÃ“. En buena hora volvÃ­ al ruedo... lo encontrÃ© inspirador y sincero y hasta un poquito mÃ¡gico. Me encantÃ³ la visiÃ³n del autor, tan asiÃ¡tica, en el sentido de que acepta la realidad y la naturaleza como son... en vez de intentar modificarlas a nuestra manera occidental, y me encantÃ³ tambiÃ©n su visiÃ³n sobre lo importante que es trabajar en lo nuestro, aunque nuestras existencias sean breves y nuestros resultados limitados, y la misma naturaleza a lo macro no nos ayude. TambiÃ©n me encantaron las metÃ¡foras y las historias. Una de mis partes favoritas fue cuando le preguntÃ³ a un oftalmÃ³logo si conocÃ­a a alguien que hubiera podido salvarse de la presbicia (ir perdiendo la vista por el mero envejecer) y Ã©ste le contestÃ³ que no. Fue como que Murakami tratÃ³ de ver si se podÃ­a ser inmortal pero ya que le djeron que no, buÃ©h, al mal tiempo buena cara. Todo el diÃ¡logo fue hecho con muy poca animosidad. Lo encontrÃ© tierno y un tanto tragicÃ³mico.Con tal que al final todo me gustÃ³ mucho y ademÃ¡s me sentÃ­ identificada porque, aunque yo no corro, siempre he sido buena para caminar, y para caminar durante horas, casi todos los dÃ­as, y al igual que Ã©l prefiero hacerlo en soledad... esa sensaciÃ³n de borrarse de todo... es deliciosa. Y muy importante para la paz mental. Yo tambiÃ©n la necesito de una manera mÃ¡s honda de lo que puedo expresar. Es como si uno refloreciera en ello. Cuatro estrellas y no cinco solo porque en ocasiones me cayÃ³ un poquitÃ­n mal. A veces lo encontrÃ© un tanto presuntuoso y despectivo, y tampoco me gustÃ³ cÃ³mo hablÃ³ del calentamiento global. Pero el libro es GENIAL. Sincero, inspirador, y yo fui muy feliz, porque hace mucho pero mucho tiempo que no leÃ­a algo que me inspirara. SaquÃ© muy buenos tips de Ã©l. SubrayÃ© como una loca, cosa que no hago a menudo. Todo lo que dice del correr puede aplicarse a cualquier otra cosa que uno quiera lograr en la vida.Citas que destaquÃ©, que fueron MUCHAS. Se me anduvo pasando la mano, jejeje.1.Pain is inevitable. Suffering is optional. (esto salÃ­a en la polera de alguien en una maratÃ³n).2.En la profesiÃ³n de novelista, al menos para mÃ­ no hay victorias ni derrotas. Tal vez el nÃºmero de ejemplares vendidos, los premios literarios, o lo buenas o malas que sean las crÃ­ticas constituyan una referencia de los logros obtenidos, pero no los considero una cuestiÃ³n esencial. Lo mÃ¡s importante es si lo escrito alcanza o no los parÃ¡metros que uno mismo se ha fijado, y frente a esto no hay excusas. Ante otras personas, tal vez, uno pueda explicarse en cierta medida. Pero es imposible engaÃ±arse a uno mismo.En ese sentido, escribir novelas se parece a correr un maratÃ³n. Por explicarlo de un modo bÃ¡sico, para un creador, la motivaciÃ³n se halla, silenciosa, en su interior, de modo que no precisa buscar en el exterior ni formas ni criterios.3.Si uno lo piensa, quizÃ¡ este punto de vista tambiÃ©n sea aplicable al trabajo del novelista. Los novelistas dotados de talento natural son capaces, sin hacer nada especial (o haciendo cualquier cosa), de escribir novelas con suma facilidad. Las frases les brotan como el agua mana a borbotones de un manantial, y asÃ­ va surgiendo su obra. No necesitan esforzarse.Hay personas asÃ­. Pero, por desgracia, yo no soy como ellas. No es para sentirse orgulloso de ello pero, por mÃ¡s que miro a mi alrededor, no encuentro el manantial por ninguna parte. Tengo que tomar el cincel y el martillo e ir picando poco a poco el suelo rocoso hasta abrir un profundo boquete; si no, no consigo llegar al manantial de la creatividad.Escribir una novela me exige malgastar mucha fuerza fÃ­sica. Me cuesta tiempo y esfuerzo. Cada vez que me propongo escribir una novela, tengo que empezar a cavar un nuevo agujero desde el principio. Con los aÃ±os, no obstante, uno va fortaleciÃ©ndose y dominando las tÃ©cnicas para poder cavar agujeros en ese duro suelo rocoso y descubrir nuevas vetas de agua de forma bastante eficaz. Y cuando noto que un manantial estÃ¡ a punto de agotarse, puedo pasar a abrir el siguiente con celeridad y determinaciÃ³n. Sin embargo, los que dependen Ãºnicamente de los manantiales naturales, aunque de repente se propusieran hacer lo mismo, seguramente no lo conseguirÃ­an con tanta facilidad.4.Cuando digo que corro todos los dÃ­as, hay gente que se admira de ello. A veces me dicen "Menuda fuerza de voluntad tienes, Â¿eh?". Por supuesto, me alegra que me elogien. Es mucho mejor a que te denuesten. Pero, a mi parecer, tener fuerza de voluntad no significa que uno consiga todo lo que quiere. El mundo no es tan sencillo. O, para ser franco, tengo incluso la impresiÃ³n de que entre el hecho de correr a diario y tener mucha fuerza de voluntad no existe tanta correlaciÃ³n.Que yo lleve corriendo de este modo mÃ¡s de veinte aÃ±os supongo que se debe, en definitiva, a que esa actividad va con mi carÃ¡cter. O, al menos, a que no me acusa tanto sufrimiento. Al ser humano no le cuesta proseguir con algo que le gusta, pero sÃ­ con algo que no le gusta. Supongo que la voluntad, o algo parecido a la voluntad, tiene que ver un poco con ello. Por mucha fuerza de voluntad que uno posea, por mucho que sea de los que no se dan por vencidos, si algo no le va, no podrÃ¡ hacerlo durante largo tiempo. Y, aunque pudiera, seguro que su salud se resentirÃ­a.5.El tabique que separa la sana autoconfianza de la insana arrogancia es realmente muy fino.6, al terminar una de las carreras.En un cafÃ© del pueblo de MaratÃ³n, me tomo una cerveza Amstel todo lo frÃ­a que quiero. Por supuesto, estÃ¡ buenÃ­sima. Pero la cerveza real no estÃ¡ tan buena como la que yo imaginaba y ansiaba fervientemente mientras corrÃ­a. No existe en ninguna parte del mundo real nada tan bello como las fantasÃ­as que alberga quien ha perdido la cordura.7. La cita que me cayÃ³ en desgracia sobre el calentamiento global aunque, a su favor, este libro tiene por lo menos diez aÃ±os y todavÃ­a no habÃ­a tanta informaciÃ³n tan clara.En JapÃ³n, este verano ha hecho un tiempo muy extraÃ±o. El tsuyu (tiempo de lluvias), que normalmente deberÃ­a de haberse acabado a principios de julio, se prolongÃ³ hasta finales de ese mes. Y lloviÃ³ hasta el hartazgo. Las intensas lluvias torrenciales castigaron a casi todas las regiones y se cobraron muchas vÃ­ctimas.Se culpa de todo ello al calentamiento global; puede que se deba a ello, o puede que no. Algunos cientÃ­ficos afirman que es asÃ­, y otros aseguran que no. Ciertas hipÃ³tesis se pueden demostrar, y otras no. Pero la gran mayorÃ­a de los problemas a los que se enfrenta el mundo en la actualidad se imputan, en mayor o en menor medida, al calentamiento global.Si caen las ventas en la industria de moda, si las olas arrastran una cantidad ingente de troncos hacia la costa, si se producen inundaciones, si se recrudece la sequÃ­a, o si suben los precios al consumo, la responsabilidad se la lleva en su mayor parte el calentamiento global. Lo que necesita el mundo es un malvado concreto, con nombre y apellidos, al que poder seÃ±alar con el dedo y espetarle "Â¡La culpa es tuya!".7.Los tiempos individuales, el puesto en la clasificaciÃ³n, tu apariencia o cÃ³mo te valore la gente, no son mÃ¡s que cosas secundarias. Para un corredor como yo, lo importante es ir superando, con sus propias piernas y con firmeza, cada una de las metas. Quedarse convencido, a su manera, de que ha dado todo lo que tenÃ­a para dar y que ha aguantado como debÃ­a. Ir extrayendo alguna enseÃ±anza concreta (no importa lo nimia que sea, pero que sea lo mÃ¡s concreta posible) de las alegrÃ­as y los fracasos. Y, a base de tiempo y de aÃ±os, ir acumulando una por una carreras de ese tipo para, finalmente, sentirse satisfecho. O tal vez, aproximarse, siquiera un poco, a algo parecido a eso (sÃ­, tal vez esta expresiÃ³n sea mÃ¡s adecuada).

Perhaps his translator is partly at fault -- I don't speak Japanese, so it'd be impossible for me to check -- but I can't help blaming Haruki Murakami himself for how badly written and uninteresting "What I Talk About When I Talk About Running" is. Given that he does speak, read and translate English, I'm assuming Murakami looked over the English translation of this book before it was published, so I'm holding him responsible. A memoir mostly of his life as a runner of marathons and competitor in triathlons, but also of his career as a novelist, "Running" pales miserably in comparison to the fiction of his I've read, including "The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle," "Hardboiled Wonderland and the End of the World," and countless short stories.My chief complaint about "Running" is its language. It's so full of meaningless adverbs and adjectives -- "really," "pretty," "definitely," "very," "extremely" and twice, I swear to God, Murakami corrects himself to say he meant "extremely" rather than "very" -- that one would think he'd never written a book before. "Running" also is teeming with clichÃ©s -- and not just any clichÃ©s, but really annoying ones such as, I'm not kidding, "raining cats and dogs." It's been a while since I've read any of Murakami's novels, and maybe my memory is failing me, but he didn't rely on such weak language in them, did he? Aside from the poor writing, Murakami has few interesting things to say about either being a runner or being a novelist. For much of the book, he just prattles on and on about how this is how or why he runs, or this is how or why he writes, and that's just how he is, and other people may do it differently. He offers no great insights into either activity. I haven't read much about running, but Raymond Carver -- one of Murakami's idols, and, as the author of "What I Talk About When I Talk About Love," the source of this book's title -- offers dozens more insights into the art of fiction in the five and a half pages of his essay "On Writing" (of which Murakami is surely familiar) than in the pages upon pages Murakami devotes to the topic in this book. And that's not to mention all the weather talk. Jesus, Haruki, stop with the goddamn weather. Yes, I know weather must be quite important to runners, but enough about the weather already, especially if you can't find anything more interesting to say about it than how, as mentioned earlier, it was "raining cats and dogs."I'm tempted to give this book one star, but my past enjoyment of Murakami's books -- and the fact that I'm not a runner myself, meaning I may have overlooked some of "Running"'s highly elusive pleasures -- compel me to be generous and give it two. Before "Running" came out, The New Yorker ran an excerpt from it that was relatively concise and enjoyable. I, and perhaps Murakami too, should probably have stopped with that essay. And, from here on out, maybe he should stick to fiction.

â€œI just run. I run in a void. Or maybe I should put it the other way: I run in order to acquire a void.â€.This book is a biography/memoir of writer and runner Haruki Murakami.Finally, we will be able to find more about Murakami, the writer who stole our hearts and minds.When you read this book, you feel that you are listening to your best friend, who is telling you everything about his life that you didnâ€™t know before.And that's why I didn't like to finish this book, because I felt that I was going to lose touch with Murakami, I would lose my dear friend.Here we find him talking about running, sports, and how to live a healthy life.We can see him as a normal person who is suffering from his body pain, afraid of gaining weight, and being nervous about the idea that his wife might tell people about his personal secrets.We might see his slightly pessimistic side, but maybe he is just thinking the way I am thinking â€œAlways expect the worstâ€ to not to be surprised by what will happen later.Murakami choose sports life especially running his own way of life, making the running and writing two sides of the same coin, canâ€™t give up on either one of them, because in his opinion he must run to be able to write.He made his own rules that canâ€™t be broken, he made himself a lifestyle suitable for Murakami character, the human being, writer, and runner.The book is so lovable, his writing style was fun and easy to read, he talked about himself honestly and directly, he didn't hide this time behind the characters that he created.I wish this book never ended, and he talked more about his personal life, his love life, about his wife, and his writing style. But maybe we will have another chance to read another personal book that talks more about his secrets.I recommend this book to all Murakami lovers,who wants to discover a new side of him..Haruku Murakami1949-20**Writer (and Runner)At Least He Never Walked.

My brushes with Murakami's fiction have given poor results at best. But, this little memoir on running is quite different. I don't really care for running. Nor any kind of sport for that matter. Yet I still found this very interesting. Whilst the author gets ready to rung his yearly marathons, he contemplates his life's choices and makes some very interesting observations. He speaks of success and failure, of not meeting one's goals to the fullest, of making decisions that ultimately paid off, etc. Without giving anything else away, I'd like to urge my friends to read this and discover for themselves why this is worth a read. I barely finished it and I'm thinking of rereading so that should explain a lot.

What I Talk about When I Talk about Running by Haruki MurakamiMy rating: 4 of 5 stars
As close to a Murakami memoir as we're likely to receive for quite some time.
I'm not making any secret of it, I am two weeks shy of my 30th birthday (original text written previously, obviously because I just wrote my brithday blogpost) and my health and fitness levels have been at all time lows in the past twelve months. I think back to when I was a younger man and wonder about the transition from athletic boy to lazy teen to lethargic man and I hardly recognise myself. This was something I couldn't stand the thought of, egged on by the distinct possibility of groaning from exertion whenever I lifted a book in the future I have been steadily working on my fitness for the past month with the aid of the C25K (couch to 5km) running program.One of my least favourite things about exercise is the clothes that people wear, lycra seems far too popular and offensive to my eyes and don't get me started on those shoes they sell these days. It's virtually impossible to get an ordinary white pair of runners these days. Everything comes in neon with padding here, cushioning there, auto corrective-this and anti-that to the point that you may as well not run because the shoe is doing all of the work. I decided that if I was going to exercise I was going to do it on my own terms and be myself not another neon lycra clad automaton and so I came up with a simple outfit that reflects my semi-hipster nature and got in to some serious shoe research on the internet. 





    
      My Nike Pre Montreal Racers: No gimmicks, just running
    
    
Hands up who knows about Steve Prefontaine? I didn't, beyond the fact that Hollywood made TWO biopics of him in quick succession (played by Jared Leto and Billy Crudup) and that he was supposed to be good at running. Turns out Prefontaine is credited with some sort of boom in running back in the 70s and Nike designed a shoe for his Montreal Olympics run (SPOILER ALERT which he never made it to because he died in a car accident at the age of 24,) he also sported a mean moustache which despite my best hipster intentions I could never match.My thoughts; if they were good enough for a running legend like Prefontaine back before technology became so prevalent then dammit they are good enough for me. I must say I love them, if they weren't so blue I'd probably try to find a way to wear them everywhere I go.The idea behind learning to run without all the advanced technology is for my body to be able to cope with the physical act in any circumstances, what use is it getting fit if you have to run for the bus in your work shoes or worse than that, need to outrun some sort of mugger on a murder death kill rampage and can't because you can only run in super cushioned air bubble shoes? It's going well so far, but remember people it's not about the shoes, it's a state of mind.










    
      Day 1: One is not enthused
    
    
Haruki Murakami is one of those authors who has managed to capture my imagination with his prose from the very first time I opened one of his novels. Dance Dance Dance is a benchmark for the kind of literature I wish I could write and I dream of somehow capturing the ennui of 21st century life that he seems to describe with ease in every script I ever conceive. This book, originally bought to encourage Leah in her running pursuits, seemed like the perfect match for where I currently am in my life. I wasn't disappointed.He discusses the way he approaches his runs, why he does it, the way they make him feel and the comparison to writing novels. He doesn't offer tips, this isn't a training log, it's just a document of his thoughts on his career as a running writer and dealing with getting older. Having gotten to the stage of running 5km without too much pain in my out of practice limbs I am starting to feel good about it, with the gently encouraging and optimistic words of Mr Murakami I am feeling even more positive. He makes me want to keep running, to increase my distances, to run marathons. Hell, even being 10 days in to NaNoWriMo without having written a word I even feel positive about my writing abilities. He writes about the ordinary and everyday things with an eye and a voice that is unmatched in contemporary literature and this is reflected in his outlook on his own life.Whilst this slight collection of writings will primarily appeal to runners, to a lesser extent writers, there is a beauty in his approach to life that will fascinate the casual reader of non-fiction work.Originally posted at Blahblahblahgay

Lettura piacevole e scorrevolissima. Un vero e proprio inno alla perseveranza che perfeziona e contribuisce ad affinarci anche spiritualmente. Un viaggio tra esercizio fisico, scrittura e la filosofia di vita che li accomuna.

For some reason, GR lists me as having read this book before. If I have, I don't remember it. In fact, this book stands out in my memory as having been the only Murakami I (a huge Murakami fan) had not read.I was prejudiced because, although years ago, I ran (badly but with great pleasure), I thought a book about running would be dull to a non-runner. However, I loved it. Murakami believes his running enables his writing, that both long-distance running and writing novels require stamina and physical (not just mental) strength.Although I was never as good a runner as Murakami, I felt my experience was similar to his in a number of ways. I hated getting out of the bed in the morning to run (as I am reluctant now to get up to write) but once I was out running, I was glad. I found running difficult although I found a great deal of pleasure in it, which Murakami, surprisingly, either doesn't or doesn't express. But I shared his satisfaction in overcoming pain and emotional resistance and the desire to meet my own standards as well as gain physical strength for the rest of my life. Not running exactly as exercise but running as a way of, or metaphor for, living.The style of the book is conversational and open. There are not many chances to get a look into this writer's mind so I welcomed this aspect of the book. I also found his remarks about the process of his writing and glimpses of his life fascinating. I guess I'm a true fan girl, which is why reading this book was inevitable.I'm glad I waited since it gave me something to read between the novels. Now I've read everything but Birthday Stories. I guess that's next on my list.Murakami seems to be an understated kind of person but that might belie his passion. It's hard to imagine that anyone who writes as brilliantly as he does (although often with a detached voice) could not have deeper emotions than he shares in this novel.Until the end, this was a 5 star read. For some reason, the end seemed flat to me, the book tapering off to a finish instead of, pardon the analogy, running full force to the end.Nevertheless, I loved most of this book. It was great just to be in the presence of this great writer. I could hardly stop reading. Favorite line: "sometimes taking time is actually a shortcut." Something for me to remember.

I picked up this book hoping to get an inspiration for running. I've never been much of a runner and hoped that Murakami could change that.Certainly feels like I'm buzzing and want to give myself the confidence to try running more. He also touched on subjects about writing and swimming which all spoke to me on another level and hopefully I will stay to be inspired to get on with something. As I'm going to Japan in two weeks (!!), I found it especially cool that I recognised many places (from planning the trip) he mentioned. I'm sure I liked the book even better because this.

What goes on in the minds of endurance athletes? What drives them? What is the impetus or nature of this obsession? The key to fomenting understanding of these things lies in the mind of an artist. Murakami is a bit of a Rosetta stone for non endurance athletes, opening a window to those driven souls. It was fascinating to hear the inner monologue that happens in a creative mind. There is something strange about people who are driven to endurance sports. The conventional wisdom is that these are people who enjoy suffering. Not suffering for its own sake, but suffering and then prevailing in spite of the pain or as Murakami would say, because of the pain. "Of course it was painful, and there were times when, emotionally, I just wanted to chuck it all. But pain seems to be a precondition for this kind of sport. If pain weren't involved, who in the world would ever go to the trouble of taking part in sports like the triathlon or the marathon, which demand such an investment of time and energy? It's precisely because of the pain, precisely because we want to overcome that pain, that we can get the feeling, through this process, of really being alive--or at least a partial sense of it. Your quality of experience is based not on standards such as time or ranking, but on finally awakening to an awareness of the fluidity within action itself." "In most cases learning something essential in life requires physical pain.""Pain is inevitable. Suffering is optional."The thing about endurance sports is that they require tremendous amounts of time. Lots of time is needed to train effectively. Endurance sports give the athletes time to think. Time to process. Time to work things out. Time alone. What people do with that time is fascinating: "I'm the kind of person who likes to be by himself. To put a finer point on it, I'm the type of person who doesn't find it painful to be alone. I find spending an hour or two everyday running alone, not speaking to anyone as well as four of five hours at my desk, to be neither difficult or boring.""I just run. I run in void. Or maybe I should put it the other way: I run in order to acquire a void."Murakami reveals that he is incredibly focused, and disciplined and very hard on himself. I didn't generally think of an author of fiction as driven. Shortcoming on my part to be sure. In my experience success requires focus and discipline and by extension successful people (even creative people) are extremely focused and disciplined. But running here is more of an obsession and it takes a gifted writer to translate the why's of this obsession:"What I should be looking at is inside ofÂ me. Like staring down into a deep well. Can I see kindness there? No, all I see is my own nature. My own individual, stubborn, uncooperative often self-centered nature that still doubts itself--that, when troubles occur, tries to find something funny, or something nearly funny, about the situation. I've carried this character around like an old suitcase, down a long, dusty path. I'm not carrying it because I like it. The contents are too heavy, and it looks crummy, fraying in spots. I've carried it with me because there was nothing else I was supposed to carry. Still, I guess I have grown attached to it.""Being active every day makes it easier to hear that inner voice.""An unhealthy soul requires a healthy body.""When Iâ€™m criticized unjustly (from my own viewpoint, at least), or when someone Iâ€™m sure will understand me doesnâ€™t, I go running for a little longer than usual. By running longer itâ€™s like I can physically exhaust that portion of my discontent. It also makes me realize again how weak I am, how limited my abilities are. I become aware, physically, of these low points. And one of the results of running a little farther than usual is that I become that much stronger. If Iâ€™m angry, I direct that anger toward myself. If I have a frustrating experience, I use that to improve myself." He is a superb amateur runner. He expects quite a bit from himself. He also acknowledges the selfishness inherent in endurance sports. Even in races with thousands of people, it is a solitary event. As previously stated, these things take enormous amounts of discretionary time that could be spent with family, friends etc. The irritation when someone or events get in the way. He talks about how athletes are sometimes at war with themselves, struggling to put in the effort in spite of the lethargy and desire to do other things. He talks about how his body got used to the movements and the pounding and how mentally and physically he got dependent on running and how it makes him feel. Most of all he talks about how running heightens (my words not his) his self-awareness."No matter how mundane some action might appear, keep at it long enough and it becomes a contemplative, even meditative act.""Whether it's good for anything or not, cool or totally uncool, in the final analysis what's most important is what you can't see but can feel in your heart.""In certain areas of my life, I actively seek out solitude. Especially for someone in my line of work, solitude is, more or less, an inevitable circumstance. Sometimes, however, this sense of isolation, like acid spilling out of a bottle, can unconsciously eat away at a person's heart and dissolve it. You could see it, too, as a kind of double-edged sword. It protects me, but at the same time steadily cuts away at me from the inside."The height of failure in running for Murakami is to walk. He is relentless both in his workouts and in races. His proposed epitaph: "At least he never walked."My thoughts on the book was that I loved it and my take away is that Murakami is a badass. He vows to keep running until he can't run anymore. My guess is that day is decades away for this (as of this review) 68 year old man. "The end of the race is just a temporary marker without much significance. Itâ€™s the same with our lives. Just because thereâ€™s an end doesnâ€™t mean existence has meaning. An end point is simply set up as a temporary marker, or perhaps as an indirect metaphor for the fleeting nature of existence." I would like to be that tuned into running. For me the concept isn't foreign, I just don't feel that passion for it. But I respect and love Murakami for his ability to both experience and articulate his passion. Lightning in a bottle. It can't be caught. But I have the same feelings towards cycling so know it to be trueâ€¦Almost 4.5 StarsI listened the audiobook. Ray Porter was the narrator. He did a fine job.

Most runners run not because they want to live longer, but because they want to live life to the fullest. If you're going to while away the years, it's far better to live them with clear goals and fully alive then in a fog, and I believe running helps you to do that. Exerting yourself to the fullest within your individual limits: that's the essence of running, and a metaphor for life â€” and for me, for writing as whole.In this anecdotal running-centric memoir, Murakami gives all his interested readers rare insights into Murakami the man and the writer, but to avid runners there is the added bonus of feeling they know him intimately in a way that runners get to know one another. For those of us that enjoy his books and love to run, this is a great read at a spectacular cross-roads and one that begs to be kept on the shelf to be read as one progresses through life as a reader and long distance runner (I can only imagine what it might add to be a writer as well). This book centers on how Murakami's life as a runner came to be and how it has developed, evolved, and how it has influenced and been influenced by the other major factors in his life - especially writing. It's fairly simply written, but still lovely. The writing is friendly and approachable, but still has his unique writer's voice emanating throughout. There are parts that are meditative and philosophical, yet others that are comical and self-deprecating, often these things seamlessly flow into one another.Personally for me there were many times that I found myself nodding as he related experiences or even motives:I just run. I run in void. Or maybe I should put it the other way: I run in order to acquire a void.Or:I'm often asked what I think about as I run. Usually the people who ask this have never run long distances themselves. I always ponder the question. What exactly do I think about when I'm running? I don't have a clue.And certainly:At around twenty-three miles I start to hate everything. Enough already! My energy has scraped bottom, and I don't want to run anymore. I feel like I'm driving a car on empty. I need a drink, but if I stopped here to drink some water I don't think I could get running again. I'm dying of thirst but lack the strength to even drink water anymore. As these thoughts flit through my mind I gradually start to get angry. Angry at the sheep happily munching grass in an empty lot next to the road, angry at the photographer snapping photos from inside the van.The sound of the shutter grates on my nerves. Who needs this many sheep, anyway?I largely read this book as a runner and so much of the running parts were familiar to me, though the specifics differed (I have never run in Hawaii, Japan, or been unreasonably resentful of sheep while running- cows yes, but never a single sheep that I can recall), but the feelings and experiences in general felt true and recognizable. As a fan of Murakami's I was not disappointed by the glimpses into his writing process or his approach to writing either, but again I read this more as a runner, so that came somewhat secondary for me. Hell, I even timed my reading of this book to coincide with the fall marathon season. As I write this I am one week out from the marathon I have been training for and it is one day before some running friends will be participating in the New York Marathon, which is the race that Murakami is training for for a good portion of this book. This was simply the perfect book to be reading at this time. â€œI'll be happy if running and I can grow old together.â€ Me too, and I think this book may help me along that path.

This is an example of (re)reading a book at the perfect time: I've been struggling with my writing lately, and I've taken up running. Obviously, this memoir has a relevance to me that it lacked before (hence the rating increase). I found this really inspirational, in Murakami's typically quiet, understated way. (I hadn't read anything by him in a while and I just felt so soothed from page 1.) I hope I can take it to heart, both when I run and when I write.***Original Review***Yet another way in which Haruki Murakami is more awesome than you: not only does he write amazing novels and nifty short stories, heâ€™s also a long-distance runner whoâ€™s raced in marathons, triathalons, and even a day-long supermarathon in Hokkaido. This book, the first piece of nonfiction Iâ€™ve read by him, chronicles a year in his life as a runner. I liked it less than his fiction. Parts are slow: the endless tally serious runners have to make of distances run in such-and-such lengths of time. I liked the book best when Murakami was talking about a specific event, such as running the original marathon course in Greeceâ€”when he was telling a story, in other words. I also really liked when he talked about being a novelist in comparison to being a runnerâ€”both require discipline and the ability to go the distance. This book is one of the things that inspired me to work on my own stupid novel every damn day.Iâ€™m glad I read this, but I wouldnâ€™t recommend it unless youâ€™re a) really into running or b) have recently become a big Murakami fangirl, like some people I could mention.

I love Murakami's dreamy magical realist novels. And I love distance running. So when I heard Murakami had written a book about his experiences as a runner, I figured it would be right up my alley. I was terribly disappointed. The book literally reads like a diary. Here's a typical paragraph: "Out the window of my campus office I watched the snowflakes falling. My physical condition isn't too bad. When I get too tired from training, my legs tend to get heavy and my running is unsteady, but these days I feel light as I start off. My legs aren't so tired anymore, and I feel like I want to run even more." Are they just letting Murakami publish whatever he wants these days? He's a genius, but this is just a genius's boring old running diary. There are sections where he considers how running is similar to writing (isolating, slightly perverse, etc), and he has interesting observations--but here there is none of the creativity he shows in his novels. I wouldn't even call it "creative non-fiction," it's so lacking in creative description.Oh, and I think his running practices are dumb. He goes on and on about his marathon times and his disappointment when he doesn't improve his performance, and he's proud of never talking walk breaks. Lots of marathoners take walk breaks, and most do it not for the PR but the experience! Relax and enjoy your run, Murakami.

when i first heard about this book i thought of a kind of â€˜pre-reviewâ€™ which was â€˜i hate running but murakami loves it so good for him.â€™â€¦â€¦..but then i actually started running so the lesson here is that people change! i will never run a marathon though i would rather just donate the money to charity and not do it.

3Â½ starsHaruki Murakami is new to me, but evidently not to many: he has quite a number of fans on Goodreads. I decided that by way of introduction, I would begin with reading his Memoir because the title suggests itâ€™s about running, and I like to think of myself as a runner. The book jacket goes further, telling us that Murakami reflects upon the influence running has had on, not only his life, but, more importantly, on his writing. He runs; I run. He writes novels; Iâ€™m writing a novel. Why wouldnâ€™t I pick it up?Now that Iâ€™ve read it, I wouldnâ€™t say I regret doing so, but I confess I was a little disappointed to discover that references to running -- mainly marathons, actually -- far outweighed comments connecting the sport with his writing. And thatâ€™s another thing. I didnâ€™t think this book was that well written, overall. But I am sure novel-writing is his strength, so I havenâ€™t â€œwritten the guy offâ€, so to speak. I gave this book three stars because parts of it are well written, and I definitely could relate to much of it. As Haruki says, â€œEven if the skill level varies, there are things that only runners understand and share. I truly believe that.â€ As do I. And when he does talk about writing, he has specific things to say. For instance, he says that the most important quality a novelist has to have is talent: â€œIf you donâ€™t have any fuel, even the best car wonâ€™t run.â€ The next important quality for a novelist to have is focus; that if you have focus, â€œyouâ€™ll be able to compensate for an erratic talent or even a shortage of it.â€ And after focus, â€œthe most important thing for a novelist is, hands down, endurance.â€ Both distance-running and distance-writing require focus and endurance. He says youâ€™ll naturally sharpen both by sitting down every day to write; likewise with daily running â€“ by running, that is, not sitting down. â€œAlmost imperceptibly youâ€™ll make the bar rise.â€ But what made me smile, and the reason for the extra half-star: Writing novels, to me, is basically a kind of manual labor. Writing itself is mental labor, but finishing an entire book is closer to manual labor.... Most people, though, only see the surface reality of writing and think of writers as involved in quiet, intellectual work done in their study. If you have the strength to lift a coffee cup, they figure, you can write a novel. Butâ€¦ sitting at your desk, focusing your mind like a laser beam, imagining something out of a blank horizon, creating a story, selecting the right words, one by one, keeping the whole flow of the story on track â€“ requires far more energy, over a long period than most people ever imagine. You might not move your body around, but thereâ€™s grueling, dynamic labor going on inside you. Everybody uses their minds when they think. But a writer puts on an outfit called narrative and thinks with his entire being; and for the novelist that process requires putting into play all of your physical reserve, often to the point of overexertion. This is so true. And it is why I try to make myself take a break, go for a run. It not only allows me to stretch my limbs, it allows me to let my brain run free. Murakami says that expressions on the faces of people who run regularly are all the same: they look like theyâ€™re thinking about something as they run even though they may really be thinking about nothing at all. This reminded me of when I used to run 10 km at least six days a week. I did that for years. Unlike Haruki, though, I never did and never do, listen to music when I run. I take in the scenery, and as I said, allow my mind to wander. When on a run as a break from working on my novel, I have learned that carrying a notepad and small pencil is a must, because if I donâ€™t, any idea â€” and there will always be an idea, or Iâ€™ll realize I need to change something â€“ will get lost in the wind if I donâ€™t stop to write it down. I learned this lesson when I found that repeating an idea over and over again until arriving back home didnâ€™t work, either. Running and mind-wandering go together. So who is this book for, really? Anyone who either runs marathons or participates in triathlons or does both, would at least find a kindred spirit in this author. Actually, I donâ€™t race anymore, and the longest race I ever participated in was a half-marathon, but it was interesting reading about his training, the inevitable pain, his aging, and how that has changed what he can expect from his body. Yes, aging means one must adapt, something Iâ€™ve certainly had to come to terms with, as has Haruki Murakami. An interesting man; I must read something else by him. I have decided on Norwegian Wood. That is, unless anyone has a better suggestion.

La mia videorecensione: https://youtu.be/Ga_TLtciiaoVi sembrerÃ  strano ma invece di comprare 1Q84 di Murakami ho preso L'arte di correre. PerchÃ©? Prima di tutto perchÃ© mi attirava il titolo, in secundis perchÃ© non volevo iniziare un suo romanzo ma una sua opera diciamo meno impegnativa come questa che Ã¨ una sorta di diario di viaggio. Qui l'autore giapponese ci narra la sua personalissima esperienza di corridore e anche di scrittore, cose che entrambe lo affascinano e che nella sua vita combaciano in maniera perfetta. Mi Ã¨ piaciuto. E molto. Murakami scrive senza censura, come se parlasse con se stesso, e in effetti ci rivela nella prima pagina "la regola vuole che un vero gentiluomo non parli delle sue ex fidanzate, nÃ© delle tasse che paga [...] Io, perÃ², non sono un gentiluomo, quindi del galateo me ne infischio. Tuttavia provo un leggero imbarazzo a scrivere questo libro, benchÃ© non si tratti di un manuale di igiene fisico-mentale, ma di un testo sulla corsa a piedi [...] Voglio solo fare alcune riflessioni, o forse un soliloquio, su ciÃ² che ha significato per me, per la mia persona, praticare la corsa per tutto questo tempo". Intanto scopriamo che Murakami, quando corre, ascolta la musica. Soprattutto i Lovin' Spoonful, Carla Thomas, Otis Redding, Eric Clapton, Rolling Stones, Vernon Duke, Brian Adams e molti altri.Il testo di Murakami fissa il periodo di tempo che va dall'estate del 2005 fino all'autunno del 2006. L'autore ci parlerÃ  come un compagno di corsa, svelandoci la sua vita privata, i suoi gusti letterari, come sono nati i suoi primi romanzi, le fatiche e le gioie che gli ha riservato la vita. Ed Ã¨ bello come ci descrive proprio il suo primo approccio alla scrittura: "Stavo per compiere trent'anni. Ero arrivato a un'etÃ  in cui non potevo piÃ¹ definirmi "un giovane". CosÃ¬ ho concepito il proposito di scrivere dei romanzi - una cosa che non mi era mai passata per la mente prima di allora. [...] Era il 1Â° aprile 1978, verso l'una e mezzo del pomeriggio. Quel giorno, seduto sulla gradinata dello stadio di Jingu, guardavo una partita di baseball bevendo una birra. [...] Hilton fece una battuta a terra lungo la linea sinistra del campo - il suono secco della palla contro la mazza risuonÃ² nello stadio - poi a velocitÃ  pazzesca girÃ² la prima base e si fermÃ² sulla seconda. Ecco, fu in quel momento che mi colpÃ¬ il pensiero 'voglio scrivere un romanzo'. [...] Mi recai in una cartoleria di Shinjuku, comprai una risma di fogli e una stilografica da circa mille yen. Un piccolo investimento di capitale. Questo succedeva in primavera, in autunno avevo finito di scrivere un'opera di duecento fogli da quattrocento caratteri. Mi sentivo molto soddisfatto. [...] E' il romanzo che venne poi pubblicato con il titolo Ascolta la canzone nel vento. CiÃ² che mi interessava era la scrittura in sÃ©, non tanto che il libro vedesse o meno la luce".Adesso cito alcune frasi del libro che a me sono molto piaciute: "CiÃ² che mi interessa Ã¨ se riesco o meno a raggiungere gli obiettivi che io stesso mi sono prefisso. [...] Scrivere un libro Ã¨ un po' come correre una maratona, la motivazione in sostanza Ã¨ della stessa natura: uno stimolo interiore silenzioso e preciso, che non cerca conferma in un giudizio esterno. [...] L'essenziale Ã¨ superare anche di poco il livello raggiunto in precedenza. [...] Una persona riesce a costruire la propria personalitÃ  e a preservare la propria autonomia proprio perchÃ© Ã¨ differente da tutte le altre. [...] Quando faccio qualcosa, qualunque essa sia, se non mi ci dedico anima e corpo non concludo nulla, sono fatto cosÃ¬. [...] Bene o male sono arrivato alla laurea, ma non rammento di aver mai trovato, nemmeno una volta, qualche attrattiva nello studio. [...] Non si puÃ² essere simpatici a tutti, la veritÃ  Ã¨ questa".

Thank you, Murakami, for letting me peek into tiny slices of your life. why I choose this book?Murakami is one of my favourite authors and I don't let past an opportunity to voyuer into my favourite writer's lives. Hence when I got to buy this book at a discount sale by Amazon, I I was pretty sharp about ordering it asap. Though this book languished in my shelf for more than a year, it was never out of my mind. So while playing Literary bingo with few close friends, and the card read , read an author whose name starts with H, I took it as a sign from providence. Took me two days to complete it, mainly due to lack of time, but enjoyed every minute of reading, especially the first three quarters. The last quarter was slightly repetitive and I didn't like it as much.Murakami also mentions a few bits and pieces about his early years as a bar tender and his first few books...after which he concentrates mainly on running, marathons, physical training, triathlon and such. Title is apt, and is not misleading. Still, the reader in me wanted to know more about his circumstances which led to penning of individual books, especially favourites like Norwegian wood and Windup bird chronicles. But he never mentions his famous titles. Hence a bit disappointed. Have resolved to read all his works in chronological order, which means I will be 're reading a few books. But absolutely no complaints. I also got many glimpses of his love for music, and came to know of his impressive music collection.All in All, a very good read.

â€œExerting yourself to the fullest within your individual limits: thatâ€™s the essence of running, and a metaphor for lifeâ€”and for me, for writing as well.â€Murakamiâ€™s memoir about running, writing, and his outlook on life. The author took up running not long after he started writing. He eventually became a marathon runner, triathlete, and even completed an ultramarathon. This book is short and covers many parallels between what it takes to be a distance runner and a novelist. I was interested in this book due to my past efforts in marathon running, and also due to my fairly recent discovery of Murakamiâ€™s fiction. While this book is in a different category than his fiction, it is well told and insightful. I could relate to his views about solitude, focus, and competing against oneself. I would definitely recommend it to runners, as Murakami articulates what draws some people to it (and also understands it is not for everyone). While it does not reach the heights of creativity that I have experienced with his fiction, I certainly enjoyed it and recommend it. â€œIf pain weren't involved, who in the world would ever go to the trouble of taking part in sports like the triathlon or the marathon, which demand such an investment of time and energy? It's precisely because of the pain, precisely because we want to overcome that pain, that we can get the feeling, through this process, of really being alive.â€

â€œPain is inevitable. Suffering is optional. Say youâ€™re running and you think, â€˜Man, this hurts, I canâ€™t take it anymore. The â€˜hurtâ€™ part is an unavoidable reality, but whether or not you can stand anymore is up to the runner himself.â€ Iâ€™ve recently participated in a race and by the end of it, all I could think about was: why the hell am I doing this to myself over and over again? I will exert myself over something more enjoyable from now on.So this book came at a time I lost all my confidence and pleasure in running and I can say it restored my faith. He obviously has a unique character taking running to such extremes as to run at least a marathon each year, pushing himself to limits. I now have completely different respect for the author, it was a motivating book and reading about his running journey and how this fulfilling act helped him become successful in his career by clearing his mind and keeping him healthy made me look at it from a completely new perspective. Recommended for all the runners out there, either amateur or professional.â€œI've always done whatever I felt like doing in life. People may try to stop me, and convince me I'm wrong, but I won't change.â€

I can't emphasize how much this gem of a book resonated with me. Haruki's style of writing always mesmerizes me. I'm always let in a reflective and contemplative mood. This short but insightful read was no different. As I'm slowly working my way through all of Murakami's works ( this book is my fifth one of his ) I'm surprised at how all his works are layered and full of life lessons for all. I'm always a sucker for a well-written book but authors that are able to write a story and the reader is able to see parallels of greater truths underlying the main story, is worthy of the praise, of a job well done on that author's part. This book is basically a memoir of Haruki Murakami's life on how he became an author and what are some of his practices ( namely running ) that help him keep sharp at the profession that he loves. I found this so relatable to my own lifestyle that at times time I felt as though he was writing about me. Don't get me wrong I'm no runner but I do walk every single day. I love walking as it helps clear my head and helps me put things in the order that they need to be placed in my life. When I don't walk, I feel frustrated and stifled, almost clogged up and I can't seem to get my creative juices to run the way that it would normally do if I had walked. I've made it a practice of mine to carve out specific times every day for projects that I have committed to finishing. I do these religiously every day despite my feelings and have reaped the wonderful feeling of success whenever I complete a specific task I set for myself. This memoir of Murakami's mirrors a lot of my personal life story and I will definitely put this as one of my fave reads of his as it speaks to me personally.

I have a special place in my heart for Murakami, even more so after reading my first of his nonfiction books. If you've read much of his fiction, you probably won't be too surprised by his lifestyle and personality quirks. He comes across almost as one of the characters of his books, quiet, enjoys time alone, and a passionate yet methodical runner. This is actually an enchanting memoir with beautiful insights. All Murakami fans should give this one a chance. â€œPain is inevitable. Suffering is optional.â€ â€œIâ€™m the kind of person who likes to be by himself. To put a finer point on it, Iâ€™m the type of person who doesnâ€™t find it painful to be alone. I find spending an hour or two every day running alone, not speaking to anyone, as well as four or five hours alone at my desk, to be neither difficult nor boring. Iâ€™ve had this tendency ever since I was young, when, given a choice, I much preferred reading books on my own or concentrating on listening to music over being with someone else. I could always think of things to do by myself.â€ â€œAll I do is keep on running in my own cozy, homemade void, my own nostalgic silence. And this is a pretty wonderful thing. No matter what anybody else says.â€ â€œFor me, running is both exercise and a metaphor. Running day after day, piling up the races, bit by bit I raise the bar, and by clearing each level I elevate myself. At least thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve put in the effort day after day: to raise my own level. Iâ€™m no great runner, by any means. Iâ€™m at an ordinary â€“ or perhaps more like mediocre â€“ level. But thatâ€™s not the point. The point is whether or not I improved over yesterday. In long-distance running the only opponent you have to beat is yourself, the way you used to be.â€
