Questa Ã¨ stata la mia prima esperienza con Murakami e non sono rimasta delusa, infatti penso che leggerÃ² altro. In ogni caso, come dice bene lâ€™autore nella prefazione, questo non Ã¨ un vero saggio sullâ€™arte del correre, ma una sorta di memoire sulla sua vita personale e professionale, e come si Ã¨ avvicinato a questo sport.La parte che mi Ã¨ piaciuta di piÃ¹ Ã¨ stata sicuramente la prima metÃ , perchÃ¨ non era cosÃ¬ tanto concentrata sullo sport, ma parlava molto di se stesso, di cosa faceva prima di scrivere, e i suoi primi approcci al mestiere.Come lâ€™aver deciso di cambiare professione, da una piÃ¹ movimentata ad una piÃ¹ sedentaria, lâ€™avesse costretto a muoversi di piÃ¹ per mantenersi in forma e migliorare anche la sua scrittura.Ci sono tanti passaggi che ho sentito miei, che sono pensieri che ho pure io, e lui li ha espressi in maniera magnifica e mi sono sentita meno sola.Era come se fosse lÃ¬ davanti a me e mi raccontasse la sua vita: questo per farvi capire quanto era scritto bene e come scorresse.Infatti, lâ€™ho letto in un giorno, anche perchÃ¨ sono solo 146 pagine.La seconda parte Ã¨ comunque bella, ma va piÃ¹ in profonditÃ  sulle sue esperienze come corridore e parla meno di se stesso, quindi, se non si Ã¨ appassionati dalla corsa, puÃ² risultare meno interessante.Sicuramente, perÃ², mi ha fatto venire voglia di correre, e questo Ã¨ un buon segno.

3.75 stars.I genuinely think Mr Haruki Murakami could write 1000 pages about a blade of grass and keep me interested until the last page. What I Talk About When I Talk About Running is a memoir related to running. Murakami talks about different memories he has that are around different running routes, half marathons and marathons he has done all around the world. As someone who is not a runner I wasn't so sure I would find this a good read, but I really did. Even though the book does talk about running, why he runs and the places he has run, Murakami also talks about other memories and events that were happening in his life at the same time. I actually found it a very intriguing book and was not bored for a second. It is a very unique type of memoir that I have not come across before and I found it refreshing. Personally I wished the book had been longer and more in depth than it was, it definitely left me wanting more and that is why I have not given it a higher rating.If you are a Murakami fan then you will not be disappointed by this non-fiction book as it reads very much like his other works, even though it is about him. I think it's a book that anyone could pick up and be pulled in by, but especially runners. I think people who run would definitely relate to a lot of what is written and enjoy it.

What I'm talking about when I talk about runningHaruki MurakamiMemories Pages: 167.quoteI don't know; maybe I'm exaggerating. I may have run too hard and tired, and I was in my late 40s and had physical handicaps that were unavoidable for someone my age. Maybe I was accepting the fact that I was past my physical peak, or maybe I was going through depression caused by something male-related to menopause; maybe it was all these different factors coming together in a mysterious mishmash inside me. Since I am involved in this, it will be difficult for me to analyze it objectively. Whatever it was, I called it "hostility blues.Page 112..Although I don't mind reading the diaries, I love Haruki's writings very much, and I like his madness in creating the characters of his crazy novels, it was a heavy time for me until I finished this book! Perhaps, as Haruki said in the book's epilogue, "I'm not very sure I've done a good job in this field; however, when I finished, I felt like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders."He is credited with taking the title of the book from the title of a collection of short stories by his favorite writer, Raymond Kaffer..Do you like Haruki's novels? What is the best novel you have read to him? Share with us in the comments.

I just got back from a run, so this seems like the perfect time to finally write this review. While I finished this book a couple of weeks ago, with the holidays and family being around, I just didn't have the time to properly put down my thoughts about it. I wouldn't consider myself a runner. Not yet anyway. It's only recently something that I've gotten into. About a month ago. So now, while everyone is busy trying to make good on their New Year's resolutions, I can come into the New Year feeling like I'm already well into at least one of them.But no, I wouldn't consider myself a runner yet.I'm not sure how many runs one needs to complete, and in what timeframe, before they can be called a "runner" without that inkling of doubt that appears immediately afterward, the doubt that tells you you're putting on airs, that you're exaggerating, that you won't keep this up for long. Truth be told, my knee is already bothering me. It's only ever just the right one for some reason. But, assuming I keep this running thing up, I can already see a future where I might be in better physical shape but where my knees are decidedly worse. I'm not sure if I like the tradeoff but I suppose everything in life involves a tradeoff of sorts.I've been told that running on the treadmill (aka, the "dreadmill") is better on your knees, but I hate the gym, always have, and running on a treadmill is about as interesting to me as studying the gravel in my front yard, which is to say, not very.I have long been a fan of Murakami's fiction, but I put off reading this because I assumed it was something that would only interest runners. As a result then of my newfound interest in running, I finally picked it up. Nothing contained here though is inaccessible to a non-runner. For Murakami, running is essentially a sort of meditative process, albeit one that offsets the many hours he spends sitting in a chair writing and helps him stay in shape.It's a good read, filled with insight into Murakami's writing and thought process. It left me with a better understanding of the man and the reasoning behind why so many run in the first place.I recommend you add "What I Talk About When I Talk About Running" to your list for 2019, even if running doesn't make it onto your list of resolutions for the New Year.

I have been running now for a little over a year and have managed to lose a little under five stone in weight. In that time I've almost exclusively run alone (bar the odd Saturday morning parkrun) and so I picked up this book to gain some light hearted insight into the reasoning one of my favourite authors has for their own running. I don't know if Murakami still runs (I'd like to if anyone does), but I'd imagine that if he doesn't, the itch and unfortunate regret at not doing so still occasionally rears its head. Ive reached nowhere near the level he has with running, yet I found his reasoning to be much the same as my own. Bar bouts of injury or life circumstances I try to run everyday and have only recently been questioning why I'm bothering at all. I have stumbled (slowly) upon the answer which is that, bar the great mental and physical health benefits, I've found that the regime and consistent requirement I've fallen into has become somewhat addictive. There is something to be said for drumming into yourself the need to do something you don't want to do. Murakami notes a great adage about the typewriter and word counts which I thought was so apt. Plus the tangible self improvement is nice too...The obvious parallel between writing and running seems to lie in solitude. Solitude (for better or worse) and the sheer amount of time and effort required to achieve a single, finished product. Hours spent alone with nothing much to think about bar, well, whatever you want to think about. Some days when writing I feel like Murakami himself and some days when I'm running I feel like Eliud Kipchoge (for a few hundred yards). What I'm trying to say is I think the enjoyment of it for me is in the small moments of elation and the knowledge that they're fleeting and are not guaranteed to come about any time soon. When running I mostly just feel okay, and don't think about very much at all like Murakami says, but when I feel great I bottle it and (much like in my writing) try and replicate it the next day.Hopefully like the author I can look back on this review In a few years time with fond memories of my year running. Perhaps I'll still be at it, perhaps not. If I am, hopefully I'll re-read this book with a little more experience and insight and find something new that I didn't grasp this time around. Happy running! ğŸƒ

This world doesn't belong to those who can run faster, but to those who can run longer, an Extra MileThere was this time, on these wintry mornings, I used to get up early which is kind of bad-idea to a Night-hawk like me. I run for 40 minutes or so starting from my home into these awe-inspiring landscapes which would run into subsequent villages, and then I would walk all the way back home. I abdicated whole of this idea of running once summerâ€™s scorching temperatures arrived. Eighteen months later, now, I resumed my daily running and running everyday ever since I finished reading this 180 paged Murakamiâ€™s-smallest-book-till-date. No kidding. And I surmise running is never the same after reading this book, because you start to see everything in new light while you run, say that dewy grass, placid lake, foggy trees, curved path, sometimes mucky rain water, cancerous suburbs, pleasant farmland, soiled land and even anxious wild-centipede crossing the road, all of which were there earlier too, but I never cared noticed. Now i'm enjoying them.You just love the way Murakami puts these little things and philosophy into your mind and you canâ€™t stop recollecting them while you are running. Have you ever run while itâ€™s pouring down heavily? Or have you ever tried a beer just after finishing your v.long run? Now these kind of small discoveries are what you make along with running once you finish reading this book. But what I despised most about the book was demise of this interesting philosophy in running or its bond with his writing to the flat notes on few of the marathons he attended in 23 years. It just starts to get on your nerve when he starts to explain about these triathlons he started to participate lately. It just cost you one star Murakami.Murakami was 33 when he started running and he continues it till date he is 64 now.  He ran marathons every year, triathlons once in a while and meanwhile he wrote some great books. So here is the bottom line. Pain is inevitable, suffering is optional.  Thatâ€™s the effing light at the end of the effing tunnel. Now go get your shoes already!

I had read years ago a book of short stories by Murakami, and gods I hated that so much that to this day Iâ€™ve avoided all of his other books and also any kind of short stories (Although Hemingway got me back on the path at some point, so Iâ€™m just exaggerating)!Everything about this book was very friendly and smooth. And I liked his way of being open and modest at the same time, sharing his fears and struggles. I canâ€™t deny that I really enjoyed this one (Iâ€™m even considering picking another book by him! Unbelievable!). Maybe because this year I donâ€™t feel like being that much into novels but more into essays, memoirs,... the facts.. This year I feel strangely close to the end that I need to read about real stuff more than before... about life, you know... I especially loved how he bridged between running and writing. That how not paying attention to your body would affect and even ruin your career (Other jobs that involve long hours of sitting-at-desk would share the same danger).This was a great book to listen to while knitting! Especially putting it on 2x speed, helped me speed up! Now what other similar stuff to pick after? Hm... Thatâ€™s the question of the day.

A proposta desse pequeno livro de Murakami Ã© bem simples: como a corrida e a literatura sÃ£o vistas e vivenciadas pelo escritor, que nÃ£o pode se desassociar de nenhuma das duas, pois, uma Ã© equivalente Ã  outra, jÃ¡ que o escritor se exercita para que possa continuamente escrever mais.Com um relato bastante honesto de sua vida como maratonista, Murakami narra em especial o perÃ­odo de 2005-2006 quando se propÃµe, uma vez mais, correr a maratona de New York e de Boston, passando desde as suas motivaÃ§Ãµes, sua forma de ver o esporte e claro, com excelentes passagens acerca de como isso influencia sua escrita e seu processo criativo, alÃ©m de tambÃ©m discorrer de seu inÃ­cio na literatura e suas impressÃµes ao longo do tempo.Ã‰, portanto, uma obra sobre correr, sobre literatura e sobre Murakami. A quem gosta de uma dessas coisas, certamente gostarÃ¡ do romance. A mim, foi uma boa leitura, Murakami tem como meta correr uma maratona todo ano, e eu tenho a de lÃª-lo ao menos uma vez ao ano. Acho que nÃ³s dois estamos conseguindo cumprir nossas metas.

Although I am neither a runner (not even athletic to say the least) nor a novelist (I wish!), this book resonated with me and my personal struggles much more than most other books of this kind that I have read. I'm not saying this is the best book ever, because that is definitely not true; in fact I liked "Norwegian Wood" or "Kafka on the Shore" (I have only started reading books by him very recently) much more. Still, this book talks about the humane part of the writer, talks about personal struggle and happiness of small achievements set by oneself, and most importantly about sticking to a decision once fixed by someone. I could not help being more motivated and determined about doing things that I have planned for myself. Overall, I must agree with the review by Independent of Sunday, "This charming little book is a winner from start to finish". :)

I'm not entirely sure what to make of this book. I did enjoy it, as it was super interesting to get some insight into the mind of my favourite author, but it fell a little flat for me. The observations made about running, writing and life were really great. With all of Murakami's other books, I'm amazed by the natural flow of the writing. This book felt a little more disjointed, it was slightly harder to follow the train of thought. There were odd times where he would jump to talking about something else and it always threw me off. Overall I did enjoy this book! I definitely prefer Murakami's fiction writing. I just joined the gym though and this was a strangely motivating little book.

Reading Murakami gives me a mysterious joy! I donâ€™t know why I feel both happy and lucky while reading anything for him.Heâ€™s such a skillful writer who puts a lot of passion into his books and forces the reader to crave for more. Thatâ€™s a true gift.In this book, he didnâ€™t talk about running (the sport) as much as he talked about it as a writing agitator. Running for Murakami was the food of his creativity. Thatâ€™s why the reader must not think that he or she should be interested in running in order to enjoy the book. Running (the sport) is irrelevant. You can replace it with whatever sport or hobby you like and still get to enjoy and love the book.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Unlike any other works of Haruki Murakami I have read to date this being a work of non-fiction felt more special and intimate. It helped immensely in getting to know the writer better for who he is today with a little glimpse into his ordinary life. Murakami here talks about his outlook in life while unduly talking about the essence of running and marathons ; how it made him get better, push his limits and mostly always endure the utter joy as the afterglow. And with those personal stories he shared in the book, I ended up liking him more. Ps-This is a must must-read for anyone who has dearly enjoyed Murakamiâ€™s work.

HÃ¤sti mÃµnna teetassi taga lugemise raamat. Ja Murakami kirjutab ikka nii hÃ¤sti! Isegi tÃ¤iesti tavalistest asjadest, nagu see, kuidas ta iga pÃ¤ev jooksmas kÃ¤ib.Sometimes I run fast when I feel like it, but if I increase the pace I shorten the amount of time I run, the point being to let the exhilaration I feel at the end of each run carry over to the next day. This is the same sort of tack I find necessary when writing a novel. I stop every day right at the point where I feel I can write more. Do that, and the next day's work goes surprisingly smoothly.If they were to make a movie about my life I just the thought of which scares me), these would be the scenes they'd leave on the cutting-room floor. "we can leave this episode out," the editor would explain. "it's not bad, but it's sort of ordinary and doesn't amount to much." Those kinds of memories unpretentious, commonplace. But for me, they're all meaningful and valuable. As each of these memories flits across my mind, I'm sure I unconsciously smile, or give a slight frown. Commonplace they might be, but the accumulation of these memories has led to one result: me.In the novelist's profession, as far as I'm concerned, there's no such thing as winning or losing. Maybe numbers of copies sold, awards won, and critics' praise serve as outward standards for accomplishment in literature, but none of them really matter. What's crucial is whether your writing attains the standards you've set for yourself. Failure to reach that bar is not something you can easily explain away. When it comes to other people, you can always come up with a reasonable explanation, but you can't fool yourself. In this sense, writing novels and running full marathons are very much alike.In other words, you can't please everybody.Even when I run my bar I followed the same policy. A lot of customers come to the bar. If one out of ten enjoyed the place and said he'd come again, that was enough. If one out of ten was a repeat customer, then the business would survive. To put it the other way, it didn't matter if nine out of ten didn't like my bar. This realization lifted a weight off my shoulders. Still, I had to make sure that the one person who did like the place really liked it.But I don't think it's merely willpower that makes you able to do something. The world isn't that simple. To tell the truth, I don't even think there's that much correlation between my running every day and whether or not I have a strong will. I think I've been able to run for more than twenty years for a simple reason: it suits me. Or at least I don't find it all that painful. Human beings naturally continue doing things they like, and they don't continue what they don't like. Admittedly, something close to will does play a small part in that. But no matter how strong a will a person has, no matter how much he may hate to lose, if it's an activity he doesn't really care for, he won't keep it up for long. Even if he did, it wouldn't be good for him.Even now, whenever I run a marathon my mind goes through the same exact process. Up to nineteen miles I'm sure I can run a good time, but past twenty-two miles I run out of fuel and start to get upset at everything. And at the end I feel like a car that's run out of gas. But after I finish and some time has passed, I forget all the pain and misery and am already planning how I can run an even better time in the next race. The funny thing is, no matter how much experience I have under my belt, no matter how old I get, it's all just a repeat of what came before.Running every day is a kind of lifeline for me, so I'm not going to lay off or quit because I'm busy. If I used being busy as an excuse not to run, I'd never run again. I have only a few reasons to keep on running and a truckload of them to quit. All I can do is to keep those few reasons nicely polished.To deal with something unhealthy, a person needs to be as healthy as possible. That's my motto. In other words, an unhealthy soul requires a healthy body.â€œWhen Iâ€™m in Japan I rarely have to speak in front of people. I donâ€™t give any talks. In English, though, Iâ€™ve given a number of talks, and I expect that, if the opportunity arises, Iâ€™ll give more in the future. Itâ€™s strange, but when I have to speak in front of an audience, I find it more comfortable to use my far-from-perfect English than Japanese. I think this is because when I have to speak seriously about something in Japanese Iâ€™m overcome with the feeling of being swallowed up in a sea of words. Thereâ€™s an infinite number of choices for me, infinite possibilities. As a writer, Japanese and I have a tight relationship. So if Iâ€™m going to speak in front of an undefined large group of people, I grow confused and frustrated when faced by that teeming ocean of words.With Japanese, I want to cling, as much as I can, to the act of sitting alone at my desk and writing. On this home ground of writing I can catch hold of words and context effectively, just the way I want to, and turn them into something concrete. Thatâ€™s my job, after all. But once I try to actually speak about things I was sure Iâ€™d pinned down, I feel very keenly that somethingâ€”something very importantâ€”has spilled out and escaped. And I just canâ€™t accept that sort of disorienting estrangement.Once I try to put together a talk in a foreign language, though, inevitably my linguistic choices and possibilities are limited: much as I love reading books in English, speaking in English is definitely not my forte. But that makes me feel all the more comfortable giving a speech. I just think, Itâ€™s a foreign language, so whatâ€™re you going to do? This was a fascinating discovery for me. Naturally it takes a lot of time to prepare. Before I get up on stage I have to memorize a thirty- or forty-minute talk in English. If you just read a written speech as is, the whole thing will feel lifeless to the audience. I have to choose words that are easy to pronounce so people can understand me, and remember to get the audience to laugh to put them at ease. I have to convey to those listening a sense of who I am. Even if itâ€™s just for a short time, I have to get the audience on my side if I want them to listen to me. And in order to do that, I have to practice the speech over and over, which takes a lot of effort. But thereâ€™s also the payoff that comes with a new challenge."

I think I'm hitting my GoodReads "reviewing" wall because I can't seem to come up with anything interesting to say about books these days. It's all, "I loved Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore, but did you watch Homeland last night?" Or, "what did you think of Heat? Shut up, I'm listening to Babel." Or the worst one of all, "What did I think about the Murakami memoir? I'll just ignore you because I'm going to watch Cloud Atlas", which as a book I've started and stopped about 20 million times already (only a very slight exaggeration) and I bought the motherfucker in hardback when it first came out. So what did I think of What I Talk About When I Talk About Running? Umm...Hmmm...Murakami is a great writer, kind of sounds like a dick though, an uncompromising dick though. I hate when people talk about how you'll only enjoy something if you have a preexisting interest in its subject matter. I'm sorry, but that's bullshit. If you can't get it up for running or ballet or supply-side economics or killer robots or cancer just because it doesn't interest you, you need to dream a little bigger, darling. I'm not saying you're not allowed to have an aversion to a certain genre, but come up with a better reason than it doesn't interest me. I won't go near horror, but that's because I'm a pansy-ass control freak that doesn't like having nightmares about killer clowns coming out of the shower drain and stabbing me to death (I swear I didn't make that up, it was on TV when I was a wee child and that shit still makes me check the drain pipes before I take a shower, y'know, just in case). This has been a long-winded message brought to you by: Don't not read Running just because you have no interest in running. Don't read it if you don't like Murakami, or think running writers sound oxymoronic, like Hell's Angels or Microsoft Works.I happen to run and thought it might be interesting to read about running from an amateur's perspective. I'm not a good runner. I did run for an hour just before I finished this book (yes, I'm bragging), but I'm a bad runner. Murakami actually doesn't really sound like an amateur here, with all his talk of times and running down opponents and flipping them the bird (that didn't happen? oh, that was just me then), but I think any sport breaks down into beginners, amateurs, serious people, pro-amateurs, and pro-pros. Murakami is a serious runner and Running is a serious account of what he thinks about running. The writing has incredible ease and flow that only comes after umpteenth million drafts, but what stuck out to me was its honesty. Murakami is not a persona here, this sounds like a simple, direct self-portrait, scabs and all. He doesn't draw attention to his flaws (well, he does say twice that most people wouldn't like him, but that's more general), he just presents himself as truthfully as possible and doesn't give a fuck if you like him or not. I love that. I still think he sounds like a prick, but I fully admit that I'm probably a prick as well so I'm no great judge of character. The flow is nice, with subtle transitions back and forth between running, writing, and aging like a three-partner dance. Fatigue did start to set in with the running passages. They have a repetition that seems right when talking about running, but they just blurred together after a while. I had one big problem with the flow and that has to do with the New York Marathon. He keeps us informed about the training up to and including the preparation to the race, but then ends the chapter on a cliffhanger, skips ahead months in time and starts up a new topic, only coming back to tell us about the marathon after a couple pages. I really could not think of a good reason why he did this. Leave us hanging? Build suspense? Possible, but this is a short book that's heavy on philosophy, but light on plot, so to try and build suspense is stupid.

"Most runners run not because they want to live longer, but because they want to live life to the fullest. If you're going to while away the years, it's far better to live them with clear goals and fully alive then in a fog, and I believe running helps you to do that."
Running is an odd thing to be passionate about if you think about it rationally. It's repetitive, it's effortful and it's time consuming. But fellow runners will know that nothing else compares to it. What I Talk about When I Talk about Running is Murakami's way of putting into words what he has felt about running for years, since starting with a daily run of 10km that lead him to running a marathon every year, participating in an ultra-marathon (100km) and multiple triathlons. People run for different reasons: some to keep fit, some to lose or keep weight, but most will agree that it's hard to stop once you start. I wholeheartedly agree. And I love talking to people who feel the same way as I do, hearing their stories and experiences, which is why I picked up this book. Turns out I both could and couldn't relate to Murakami. We both share the determination and the knowledge that we will keep running for the rest of our days, may it be for better or worse. While I enjoy the independency of the sport, it's Murakami's way to keep himself writing: it helps him focussing. An interesting perspective. 
"I'm often asked what I think about as I run. Usually the people who ask this have never run long distances themselves. I always ponder the question. What exactly do I think about when I'm running? I don't have a clue."
Underneath all of this, there's a certain sadness though. I'd say this memoir is as much about writing and running as it is about growing older, an inevitability that I personally think a lot about. Murakami talks about the changes he can feel in his physicality, the fact that his running will keep changing (for the worse) with his growing age. There's acceptance and appreciation in his words, but I was left with a bittersweet feeling. This book is certainly an inspiring read for runners and Murakami fans alike. It was unfamiliar, thus funny, seeing his writing style and way of twisting and forming words applied to a personal story instead of his stories of magical realism and while his personal story didn't inspire me the way it did other readers, I surely don't regret having picked this memoir up.
"All I do is keep on running in my own cozy, homemade void, my own nostalgic silence. And this is a pretty wonderful thing. No matter what anybody else says."

Do you ever pick up a book and the timing is just right? Fun fact, I used to be a runner. I used to love running. I was passionate about it. I even ran a marathon! I used running during a terrible time in my life as a form of escape and it made me a better person. Sadly, I then got injured, and with injury came frustration, and after months of frustration and pain I just gave up. That was five years ago.I have wanted to start running again almost since I stopped, but I know over the past five years I have fallen deeply out of shape, and that old injury will probably never go away entirely. I will be starting from square one. Mile zero. In fact, I am in even worse shape than I was when I started running in the first place. This book brought all of the things I adore about running back. The feeling of accomplishment. The feeling of freedom that comes after a solid few kms when your muscles relax and you feel like you could run forever. The emotions that come from running races and seeing other people push themselves.So, I have dug out my old runners (the same pair I ran that marathon in) and tomorrow morning I am going to go for a run. It will be slow, it will not feel good, but I will take my time and do it. And then again the next day. And the next.If you need some inspiration for life, whether that be physical, creative, or mental, this collection of essays had me invested and is probably the best non-fiction book I have ever read. And I think that's because I found it when I needed it.

I began long distance running on November 11, 2000, at the age of 41. Since then I have run nearly 10000 miles and participated in 2 marathons and dozens of half marathons, 10Ks, and 5Ks. Running has become a bit of an obsession for me. It is something that I generally don't talk about with non runners except in very general terms. But when I talk about running with other runners -- those whom I know share, or at least understand, my obsession -- the talk often becomes alive and animated.Haruki Murakami shares my passion for running. He is generally regarded as Japan's greatest living author and is certainly the most well-known Japanese author in the Western world. I've read exactly one of his novels, Norwegian Wood, whose first chapter struck me as a brilliant emotive description of one man's nostalgia for a past love. So when I found out that Murakami is also a runner who has even written a memoir on the subject, I pretty much had to read it.A good book with a fair amount of insightful musings about running, and quite a bit about dealing with and accepting the inevitable aging process. People who have a reasonable amount of experience with long distance running will enjoy and appreciate this book.

Everything I learned about writing, I learned by running...so writes Haruki Murakami.This was the second time I read this book, but I read it three different ways this time.I bought a used Japanese edition. I read it paragraph by paragraph alongside the English edition.I read it by running. If I were truly to understand this bookâ€™s meaning this time around, I would need to run. I set a timer for 20 minutes and ran every other day. That doesnâ€™t sound like a long time, especially when you consider that Murakami ran an ultramarathon, but for me it hurt like hell.I proofread my novel-in-progress in a similar manner to the way I ran. I set a 10 minute timer and proofread the book in two 10-minute stretches every day.What am I training for? Iâ€™m training for the marathon that is my life. I want to be thinner. I want to be more disciplined. And I want a novel that is long and lean and built to last like a marathon runner.Perhaps the only way to do that is to run every day...to read every day...to proofread every day...to revise every day...but most importantly to hurt every day.

When I first made my foray into running, my husbandâ€™s favorite thing to say when I asked him if he wanted to go for a run with me was, â€œYes! Yes, letâ€™s absolutely go for a half-hour run so we can talk about it for three hours!â€ I was very much in that beginner â€œtalk-more-than-doâ€ phase (still am).Well, it turns out Haruki Murakami and I have something in common. This book is very much him talking about running. And training. And rest. And mental and physical obstacles. Parts of it are almost diary form. I was constantly reminded of my husbandâ€™s favorite quote.That said, it was not a bad thing at all. I really enjoyed his thoughts. The book was the perfect length (a little over 4 hours), so it didnâ€™t get repetitive or monotonous. It was very insightful. I listened to it on a few runs, which was surprising perfect (I normally listen to questionable rap music to keep the pace up). It really made me want to try a fictional Murakami as well.This wouldnâ€™t be for everyone, but for me, it was an almost perfect listen.

Perhaps if I've read this book some forty years ago (I know that it's published in 2007) there should have been a faint chance to start enjoying running. I didn't, so I see it only as a story about tenacity, with too few literary valences included. Quite a pity, as Mr. Murakami is always able to surprise us...

I love this book because of so many different reasons. First of all, Murakami provides great insight into the art of writing. Second of all, this book set in stone the fact that Murakami is a fucking SAVAGE. This man ran a fucking 100km marathon in 11 hours. Talk about iconic!!!
I finished this year's challenge with a memoir by a fiction writer.Who would have thought so?I picked this out of the recommendation of a productivity guru whom I dearly respect: Cal Newport.

/not a how-to book/This was my first Murakami book, and I thoroughly loved it. This man sure knows how to write. I read the first two paragraphs, and I say it out loudly, he had me. The book in itself is composed of eleven sections, and in each of which Murakami narrates a certain aspect, fact or anecdote on his (love) relationship with running -and at times just rambles about how great The Great Gatsby is. (Thatâ€™s my man. ;) Anyways, as a non-fiction book, itâ€™s just as versatile as Hemingwayâ€™s A Moveable Feast, which is probably my favourite piece of non-fiction ever. In each chapter a different race, a different mistake, a different goal, or a different comment is discussed, and at no point does it feel bland, repetitive or even boring. There is something so whimsical, powerful and simply hypnotising about someone just talking about what theyâ€™re passionate about, that the words flow by themselves. It was almost effortless to read.
â€œPain is inevitable. Suffering is optional. [...] The hurt part is an unavoidable reality, but whether or not you can stand anymore is up to the runner himself.â€
I listened to at least half of this book while Running. Iâ€™ve run regularly since my teen years, and though I loved the sport beforehand, this book has made me remember all my triumphs and pains I have dealt with. It made me love this sport even more, it reinforced it to me. Now that itâ€™s summer and I have the time, I run every other day between 30 to 90 minutes, and this book made me want to go even further. Itâ€™s really powerful stuff. It failed to make me a junkie-runner, but it is clearly stated at the forward that this isnâ€™t this bookâ€™s purpose.
â€œFor me, running is both exercise and a metaphor. Running day after day, piling up the races, bit by bit I raise the bar, and by clearing each level I elevate myself. At least thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve put in the effort day after day: to raise my own level. Iâ€™m no great runner, by any means. Iâ€™m at an ordinary â€“ or perhaps more like mediocre â€“ level. But thatâ€™s not the point. The point is whether or not I improved over yesterday. In long-distance running the only opponent you have to beat is yourself, the way you used to be.â€
And, lastly, Iâ€™d like to mention that this book is so quotable is ridiculous. Iâ€™ll read his Rat Trilogy during the autumn for sure.
- Murakami after completing his first Marathon, in the Greek town of Marathon. [Picture taken by Masao Kageyama]My recommendations for reading after this book are:- A Moveable Feast, by Ernest Hemingway [amazing non-fiction book]- The Great Gatsby, by F. Scott Fitzgerald [no questions asked]And here Iâ€™d include some Raymond Carver, but I havenâ€™t read any of his (Iâ€™m dying to). What We Talk About When We Talk About Love, inspired this bookâ€™s title, so I guess, go for that.

My three big passions are running, jazz and reading and they rank so closely together that the order changes depending on how I feel at any given time. So, when I heard that writer, jazz aficionado and distance runner, Haruki Murakami (a former Jazz club owner in Japan) had published a memoir about his love for running, I couldn't wait to read it. Well, I started this book several years ago and for some reason after reading several chapters, the excitement I had built up just wasn't there for me. I picked it up again a week ago and just finished it yesterday. Well, there are some wonderfully insightful passages in the book about running and his writing life and how he balances the two. But, for the most part it's a little humdrum. Don't get me wrong, the writing is excellent as you would expect from him. Writing about these things he's very passionate about, he could like phone most of this in (which he pretty much does). But, the writing or format is not in a linear fashion and makes the reading frustrating for me. An example, he builds you up for this 2005 NYC marathon he's training for, meticulously talking about every detail and his preparation for the race, and then right when it's time to reach the climax he switches to a triathlon race in 2006. Then he goes back to the marathon two chapters later almost like he never left it. Huh! He does this throughout the book and it's so irritating and frustrating to me. However, I will certainly take this book any day over the one fiction book I read of his. I'm still working my way through 1Q84 over 2 years later. Can you say War and Peace redux!

To be honest, I have zero interest in running; I just read this to perhaps get a voyeuristic glimpse into the brain of someone who consistently pens enjoyable off-kilter contemporary fiction: to see what makes Haruki Murakami "tick". While he still remains as enigmatic as his fiction (What I Talk About When I Talk About Running is somewhat skimpy on non-running-related aspects of his personal life), the book is still highly enjoyable. He does, in an oblique way, describe how his training regimen (for what amounts to over two decades of distance running competitions, including a few dozen marathons and triathlons, across the globe) correlates with his discipline in writing a novel. It's a lot of fun reading about his having fun doing something he totally enjoys, and almost makes me want to take up running just to see what all the fuss is about. (okay, maybe not, but his obvious love for the sport is infectious). (fun fact that definitely needs expanding upon: In his Afterword, Murakami lists a few fond memories in his (as of the 2007 publish date) two-and-a-half decade-long obsession with running. One of them was a 1983 morning jog/convo around Central Park with John Irving (whose first novel Setting Free the Bears Murakami was translating into Japanese)...how cool would it have been to hear that convo?!?! Alas, Murakami's reticence about the memory (they "talked about all kinds of things" while running...like what, Haruki?!? Please enlighten us!!!) only serves to endear me to him, while at the same time reinforces his enigmatic status. Sigh. Guess will have to wait for his tell-all autobiography...probably after he gets this running nonsense behind him.)

Videorecensione su Youtube.If I had to be objective, perhaps I'd say that yes, the book is okay, you know, nothing special.Well, objectivity can go screw itself cuz I ain't gonna be that with this little jem.What I talk about when I talk about running is a love letter to running. Murakami shares with us diary pages from ten years ago to tell us about his relationship with running, how it shaped his life and how running is inextricably interwoven with writing, how it's the physical manifestation of his personality.I run. Each morning, every single day, I get up at sunrise and go run till the sun comes up. It is my precious ritual, something that I need to do to feel good, to start my day. It is my "me" time.So Murakami's words spoke to me like nobody else's. His struggle to get up from bed when he felt too tired but he did it nonetheless for that awesome satisfactionary feeling that inevitably comes afterwards; his preference for solitary activities; the carelessness towards competition, for what matters above anything is reaching the goals that you set for yourself.This is me. This book was me in a non-fiction book form and I couldn't help but love it from start to end.Yes, I'm biased. But. If you love runnning, read this book. If you love Murakami, read this book. If you want to read a non-fiction book with a well crafted prose and short and sweet descriptions, read this book. I am aware What I talk about when I talk about running is different from Murakami's fiction, where nonsense and weirness and magical realism are the soup of the day. But it did spark my interest for this author and be sure I will hoard his other stories soon enough!

What I Talk About When I Talk About Running is a memoir by Haruki Murakami where he talks about his interest in running. From running for pleasure to competing in over twenty marathons and an ultramarathon. Part training log, travelogue and reminiscence, this is a memoir of Murakamiâ€™s passion for running.Now Iâ€™m not a runner and I donâ€™t think I ever will be but I like to read about people being passionate about a topic and although this was brief, the passion was not in short supply. Most people know Haruki Murakami for his postmodern novels which include Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World, Norwegian Wood, The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle and 1Q84. This is an unusual memoir, not just because it only focuses on one interest, but because I donâ€™t think any other authors have written something like it.The book tries to explore why he is so passionate about running and why he runs. For a non runner reading this book for its memoir aspects, itâ€™s just interesting the approach he takes. Itâ€™s like seeing Murakamiâ€™s thought process on the page; not offering tips or anything, just being nostalgic about past runs or discussing plans for a marathon or just tracking his daily runs.For me this is nothing special, but for people obsessed with running this would be an interesting read. I read just to see the passion he has towards running, as well as the fact it was mentioned in Metroland and I want to be a book hipster. I was surprised how well this worked, like a stream of conscious of Haruki Murakamiâ€™s love of running.This review originally appeared on my blog; http://literary-exploration.com/2013/...

Well,,This is my first reading to Murakami, he is a creative novelist as many said(didn't read any) he is also a great athlete. I did not expect that he started running for long distances ( i am a long distance runner too) when he was 33 Years old. Hmm, yes it's not too late but a bit late. As he claimed, running help him a lot in writing novels and in creating new magnificent narratives, in spotlight of his experience in running/ writing it proved the scientific proof that running helps the brain to release a certain chemical that make the runner feel high ''Runner's High''!! Seems he used to run instead smoking weeds just like other writers or novelist ğŸ˜¬.However, he is not only a regular runner, he just go beyond that to be an ultramarathoner ( he ran for 99 KM long!), another good experience he shared that after he ran for that tough, harsh and insane ultramarathon he felt with something he call it "Runner's Blue" that work as resistance to practice running for certain period of time, especially after a harsh run, i really understand him as i felt the same tho ğŸ™‚. Another last thing about Murakami, he is a triathlete as well swimming, Cycling, Running) Three leg in one competition, that too much tho, i never expect (may be some) such a novelist involved in such very difficult and harsh sports! But all what led him to do as he said is the passion, or let's say in another word, he did all this stuff to beat the inner Murakami in his innermost.. We all have that inner tiny stinky dwarf in ourselves who prevent us from engaging in challenges, risk or kind of new dangerous adventures. May be we can learn from Murakami how to beat that stinky dwarf ğŸ™‚

Haruki Murakami can be daunting at times. I've only read a few of his works; some I don't understand (e.g. The Elephant Vanishes, an anthology which I didn't finish) while some I don't really like (Norwegian Wood). But this book I love, because it's understandable (unlike most of his novels, that deal with the surreal) and likeable. In this memoir Murakami does not only discuss his lifelong passion for distance running, but also its relationship with his vocation as a writer and his life as a whole. He gained my greatest respect when he described himself as someone with modest talent, both in writing and running, but who always strives to do his best. He shares about dealing with his shortcomings and growing old, and in the face of all the obstacles he just keeps on going--or running, to be exact. Thanks to this book I have renewed my interest in his works, and it somehow even made me want to put on my shoes and start running. Me, someone who was always among the last to finish during runs at school.Coincidentally, the Japanese boyband member that I like has also written about running in his monthly magazine essay late last year. The translation of that essay can be found here.

Actually I'm updating my star rating to 4 because bits of this keep coming into my mind, haunting me..3 and a half stars. Haruki Murakami's memoirs about running and writing. While I said it's motivational, it doesn't read like a how to run or how to write book, it more puts you in a certain mindscape - Murakami's that is....and if you can take something from it and it enlarges your life he would be happy. It made me "feel good" about myself, and changed the way I view "failure" in sport/exercise & how you gain something new from even the failures. Writers might probably gain some insights about regularity and structure in their lives. While I'm not a writer, I can relate to Murakami's daily routines. It's the daily practice that gets you to the end of the marathon or the end of the book, ditto with any enterprise.Last but not least you find out a little about Murakami's life. Library borrow.(gets precedence since we only get 2 weeks with them).Ironic I am reading this when my foot is still out of action and it's been nearly 2 months since I've done anything but hobble. Enjoying Murakami's natural voice - it being a memoir of his thoughts about running & writing. He says it's not a philosophy but so far it's motivating me in more ways than one, even though I can't run right now.

Iâ€˜m writing this review a year after finishing the book.This book is the first book by this author that I picked up, and i have to say, Iâ€™ve never felt such a strong connection between myself and a writer before. I knew from the moment I started, that he was gonna be a favorite for me. Eventhough there wasnâ€˜t a big plot or an exciting storyline to grab onto, the way of putting the words and telling his story, made me sink into each and every page. I also run from time to time (not very often recently)And the things he felt while running in silence were just so accurate for me.On the outside running is just sweating and heavy breathing and sore legs , but itâ€˜s so much more than that.I wish I could have a conversation with him about this passion that we share and the meaning it has:))He reminded me why I love to run so much.

Such an inspiring book, this is my first read for Murakami. I know that writing novels is different, but I am really encouraged to read his novels more than before.This book is more a memoir than biography book as he described it himself, he talked about his life before his decision to devote himself to writing, his daily routine in his Jazz bar compared to his daily routine as a full time writer.One important lesson to be learned is that focus is the way to achieve any success.He talked about his experience as a runner, difficulties he had faced, bad and good times, what running meant to him, and very inspiring talks about running.Before listening, I was a bit worried that talking about running only would fill a full book, but as a talented writer, he managed to add and mix ideas to introduce a balanced meal.

Y'know, I did not love this book. I certainly wouldn't recommend it to anyone who is not a runner. It's way too specific and longwinded for a non-runner to appreciate. Here's my gripe: he's WAY too wrapped up in times and doesn't seem to enjoy long-distance running for the sake of it. For instance, he plans to run the NYC marathon one year and his goals are 1) to finish 2) to NEVER walk, only run and 3) to enjoy himself. Sorry, but I think that's crazy! Who cares if you walk for a bit? And enjoying himself is only 3rd. Hmmm....Obviously my running style differs. In any case, there are some interesting aspects to do with running as you get older, etc. but by and large it did not knock my socks off.

This is a fantastic book. Though short, it contains precious personal revelations. It allowed me to have a glimpse into Murakami's character and personal world. His passion and perseverance for running are contagious and made this book a great companion as I have started to run.

3.5 StarsI relate to Murakami in so many ways. Iâ€™m a runner and a writer. I enjoy my alone time. I am dedicated to the things I love. Iâ€™m very critical of myself and fear the decline of the body that comes with age.I found this to be somewhat inspiring, but also depressing. Itâ€™s not really an inspirational read, but more a realistic observation about life and the hard truths of dedicating yourself to a pursuit.

I ought to be the target audience for this. I very much admire Murakami and have read most of his novels. Iâ€™m also a fairly committed runner and triathlete, the subjects of his meditations in this journal-like collection of essays he wrote over about a year and a half in the middle 2000s.And yet, this one really falls flat. Thereâ€™s little sustained self-exploration: we get, for instance, the now famous declaration that he was watching a baseball game (he names the exact player at-bat) when he suddenly decided he could write a novel. Heâ€™d been running a jazz club â€“ something that comes, again, with little detail â€“ and then he decided thatâ€™s what heâ€™d do. He wrote it, sent it out, and won a contest. If it was really that easy, then I hate him. (Maybe thatâ€™s how many small-college basketball players feel about Lebron James, but stillâ€¦) If it was more complicated, as I am certain it was, then it shows him dodging some of the real material on the table.The sustained problem here is the banality. Murakami doesnâ€™t censor his observations â€“ it made him happy to run past a beautiful woman on Cambridge mornings, or he counsels high school gym coaches against insisting all students should run the same distance â€“ which generally means that he doesnâ€™t pursue any either. Thereâ€™s no thesis here, no center. There isnâ€™t even a clear narrative, since he begins by talking about distance running, with a sort of goal at the New York City marathon, and then he goes on a long tangent about bike and swimming training for unrelated triathlons. He essentially compiles a series of reflections he wrote every week or so over the period.As I reflect on this, Iâ€™m reminded of Murakamiâ€™s particular genius. His best work is filled with banality, with individuals in the midst of daily transactions with nothing spectacular about them. What makes Murakami special is two-fold, though. First, he has a gift for creating characters who are just mildly out of step with such everyday rhythms. They typically seem to fit in well and only slowly discover their own â€œstrangeness.â€In that light, â€œnormal,â€ is a fundamental concept for him. Thereâ€™s always a sense of how things should be, of how people should act, but his characters gradually become estranged from it.Second, and even more memorably, he has a gift for excavating a space beneath the normal. His characters descend, often literally, to strange depths of alternate worlds or experiences. He isnâ€™t quite a science fiction or fantasy writer â€“ his work is always anchored in our world â€“ but the cumulative effect of his magical work is to make the ground beneath us seem less solid.Read Hardboiled Wonderland. Read Wind-Up Bird Chronicle. And read 1Q84. Skip this one, though. It has the surface that Murakami punches through in his real and memorable work. Here, though, it remains at that surface, giving us a mostly superficial look at his mid-life experiences as a committed but unspectacular runner.

I thought this memoir was interesting enough to want to finish it - the author himself said itâ€™s kind of a memoir but kind of not, and a collection of essays didnâ€™t do it justice either. I picked this up largely from Ana Wallace Johnsonâ€™s booktube video because she said it was one of her favorite motivational nonfiction books.Itâ€™s a very analytical and logical (I almost want to say dry) runthrough of his journey as an entrepreneur turned novelist turned long distance runner turned triathloner. Like a lot of the reviews say, it seems like this book resonates a lot more with people who genuinely love to run as a hobby. I myself havenâ€™t tried to run since like 2016, but I wanted to give this a shot since Iâ€™ve heard a lot (both good and bad) about his fiction writing and wanted to learn more about the author himself before trying out his work.He chalks up his decisions and action of writing novels and running marathons because.. He just wants to so he does it. I can see how his story is really motivating because it really comes off like heâ€™s just a normal guy. But Murakami made some very weird comments that put me off regarding him noticing attractive young women (aka freshman at the college he lectured atâ€¦.) running past him. It was mentioned twice I think? Once in the middle and even one at the very end in his authorâ€™s note, which I felt was REALLY oddly placed and unnecessary. Like why did he feel like that was so important to mentioned at such a pivotal, closing part of the book. That was weird. Iâ€™ve heard Murakamiâ€™s fictional writing (again, havenâ€™t read yet myself) comes off as misogynistic so the fact that I actively noticed those comments.. Hmmm.. HMMMMM.. Overall I donâ€™t think I took any sage advice/wisdom from this but I donâ€™t think it was bad. There were a lot of minute details I found like were overkill, but from the reviews it sounds like it resonated with a lot of people - just not a book for me!

after reading: Goodness. This was so not what I expected. It truly is a collection of memoir-essays about running, specifically running marathons, with a splish of ultramarathons and triathlons thrown in. He does talk periodically about how running relates to writing, and how each aspect of his life has shaped and informed the other. And there is a smidge about his early, pre-writing life, how he married young and owned a jazz club and all that. But seriously? It's a book about running. So I say again: Goodness. My first thought was that it was a little disappointing, for this absolute giant of literary prowess and intellectual strangeness to be so utterly humanized and normalized, to find that, in part of his mind anyway, running is his first love, and writing second. Then (as another reader on this site mentioned), I thought the whole idea was awfully indulgent, that if he wasn't such a literary superstar, this book would never have even been considered for publication, and no one would have given a shit to read it even if it was put out. But as I kept reading, I was struck over and over again by his absolute sincerity, his total humbleness and earnestness, the simple joy and calmness with which he imparts his thoughts. I can't say that I was moved by the book, really, but it was very sweet. mid-read: I don't know if I maybe thought that the title was a lie, but I have discovered that this is actually, really a book about running. Which, as a very serious not-runner, I admit I am finding a bit off-putting. But nonetheless, I persevere...before reading: Undying thanks to my most unbearably awesome bookfriend Brian for coming through with a proof of this, and sending it across the freaking country for my utterly thrilled (I assume) enjoyment.

This was a wonderful short book. Not quite a memoir, but much more than a essay collection Murakami takes us through his experience with long distance running. As many of you will know, Haruki Murakami is one of my favourite authors (probably my absolute favourite if I'm completely truthful). His writing speaks to me on so many different levels. His characters and stories are ones that I can read over and over again. He has a magical way of storytelling and is remarkably talented. He can capture everything that I love about Japan in the essence of his words so that when I read them I'm transported back to my happy place. All of that being said I was pretty certain that I wouldn't like this. I can't run. I don't exercise and I hate sports of any kind. Why would I want to read a book about running? Well this book proves that I would read anything that Murakami puts out. It's not just about running. It's about attitudes to life, lessons that he has learnt along the path, the decisions he's made. Sure there is definitely a fair bit of talk about running. But that wasn't boring. Not in the way that Murakami talks about it. I can now appreciate what people who run themselves go through every time they lace up their running shoes. It's not something I can ever see myself doing but I feel like I've gained something from this book. I always feel that way after finishing a Murakami novel though. I'd recommend this to anyone who appreciates Murakami's way with words. And if you are a runner yourself then I think you'll enjoy this all the more. Also major plus points for the Gatsby and Raymond Carver references. I loved it, old sport.

Murakami no me gusta, pero este libro fue una recomendaciÃ³n y querÃ­a leerlo porque soy corredora de corazÃ³n, no me preocupo por distancias ni tiempos.De todo lo que dice, me quedo con la estructura que le dio a mis carreras a partir de leerlo. Es decir, hay cosas que hago habitualmente al correr y situaciones donde me siento muy identificada con Ã©l. Â¿Voy pensando cuando corro? SÃ­. Â¿Me arrepiento a la mitad -o antes- de haberme inscripto a una carrera? Obvio. Â¿Me siento capaz de terminar el recorrido? Nunca. Supongo que es su espÃ­ritu japonÃ©s que lo impera a hacer todo perfecto y querer ganar y todas esas cosas que para mÃ­ no tienen sentido. En el medio del libro sentÃ­ que perdiÃ³ la direcciÃ³n y no la retomÃ³ de nuevo, porque correr es hermoso y no un sufrimiento constante ni una manera de ser superior al resto. Correr es ese corredor desconocido que corre a la par tuya, te pasa y vuelve sobre sus pasos a buscarte, o aquel que te da un sorbo de agua mientras te morï¿½ï¿½s por llegar al puesto de hidrataciÃ³n, acÃ¡ no dice nada del que te grita "Â¡Dale, vamos, que faltan tres cuadras, que no te queda nada!" cuando en realidad todavÃ­a quedan ocho kilÃ³metros. read this in a single sitting. i couldnâ€™t put it down.pain is inevitable. suffering is optional. it was such a joy to read murakami talk about one of his greatest passions in lifeâ€”running. every word in this is injected with such vibrant fervour, such cogent tenacity that if you remove one word out from a paragraph, the narrative would tumble and feel anachronistic, like a jenga board crumbling down. you can feel the love in his very veins, that immutable and perpetual longing for the activity, something that, every time he wakes up, would get him out of bed. it is clockwork for him, and his desire to share this passion through writing was absolutely inspiring. it is concise, but he is austere and his ability to communicate what he feels while running was extraordinary. as a pianist (which can be synonymous to murakami as a runner), i felt a part of my soul exposed and written down on the very pageâ€”the lofty goals we set for ourselves, the inauspiciousness of competitions, and most of all: our potent, hyperbolic, and superlative love for the activity. it is in the very air we breathe. as we grow older, as we explore terra incognita, we may diminish or weaken in ability in the activities that we love doing (as a result of physical growth and hence deterioration), but thatâ€™s not the point. itâ€™s in the passion, the experience, itâ€™s in our brazen and emboldened heart that we keep on doing what we have been doing throughout our entire lives. i may not play all of beethovenâ€™s sonatas perfectly when i am 80, but who cares? at least i never gave up my passion. :)

Loved the tome. Murakami puts into words pieces of running insight so eloquently that the moment i finished the book, i grabbed my shoes and hit the asphalt. I stopped for a bit cause my shoes were giving me trouble, and i need to make some huaraches (or barefoot runners) probably but that is unimportant.I used to run in the beach at my old home before, and loved it. There is something glorious about simply moving your feet one after the other, propelling yourself through the air, pretty soon you barely feel in contact with the ground. When you're in form it feels like floating. Your mind is blank and yet it feels like a master computer, completely aware of your body and its immediate surroundings. You are self consumed, and the feeling is the closest I've come to actual meditation.Murakami has been running for decades. And is a much more seasoned runner than little old me. His language is so simple and insights so deep and sudden that they have the effect of a punch in the stomach. Murakami runs a marathon every year, and has inspired me to run one at least once insha Allah. There is such a thing called the Colombo Marathon for those interested in Sri Lanka, google it up.I don't know if non-runners will find this interesting. and i don't know how this compares to Murakami's other work, since i've never read any, but i can vouchsafe to this book being absolutely spiffing, old boy. Give it a go, and hit the beach.

â€œWhen I'm running I don't have to talk to anybody and don't have to listen to anybody. This is a part of my day I can't do without.â€ Reading this book a second time really gave me a greater appreciation for what Murakami says about running. Since the last time I've read this book I have taken part in at least 4 Half Marathons, I run almost every day and I sorta consider myself a runner. It is no wonder, picking up this book and reading about Murakami's love for running made me so happy. In this book, Writer Haruki Murakami tells us about his love for running, how he goes about training for a marathon and how being a runner changed him. While some of the book can be a bit repetitive, I did enjoy getting a look into what it takes to prepare for a marathon. If you are runner, I think you would definitely appreciate this book.   April 2014 I found this book was really the author's meandering thoughts about his running experience. It offered look into how he prepares for a marathon/triathlon but there wasn't anything major to write home about.

Ovaj tekst bi mogao da se zove i â€Murakami, ja te volim. Ne tvoje knjige. Volim tebe kao obiÄno-neobiÄnu osobu koja postoji da bi pisala i trÄala ili trÄala pa pisala i tako pronaÅ¡la naÄin da razume Å¾ivot svoj i ljudski; kao Äoveka koji Å¾ivi sve teÅ¡ke, samonametnute sate u patikama do pomalo Äak i suludih granica izdrÅ¾ljivosti i nema nameru da stane jer bi onda sve bilo besmisleno i, sasvim izvesno, ne bi dalo svetu sve te stranice romana. Divim se tebi kao trkaÄopiscu ili piscotrkaÄu koji odbija da, i u situacijama krajnje opasnim po Å¾ivot, hoda ono Å¡to je namerio da pretrÄi ne zato Å¡to bi drugi mogli to da vide, jer Äesto i nema nikog da te vidi kako prelaziÅ¡ te daljine, veÄ‡ zato Å¡to ti znaÅ¡ da nisi hodao veÄ‡ si istrÄao, jer tvoja savest sve vidi i prema njoj si iskren i poÅ¡ten, a to je karakter i poimanje Å¾ivota kakvo se danas retko sreÄ‡e.â€œ Ceo tekst na blogu:http://www.englishdiary.rs/o-cemu-gov...

Light, very introspective booklet. Murakami talks about his passion for running, and how that is consistent with his writing. For him that amounts to a little talent and a lot of perseverance. To me, as (former) running-addict much was recognizable, but sometimes I frowned my eyebrows, for instance as he talks about breaking the own will of his muscles. In general, I think Murakami is rather harsh on himself, almost denigrating about his many deficiencies; and at times the accounts of his preparations for running competitions were rather dull. If you're interested in Murakami-the writer, if you want to know where he gets the inspiration for his wonderful stories and how exactly he has developed his own writing style, then this book will be a disappointment.

3.75/5This is the first book of Haruki Murakami's that I have read. I have heard of his others though. I saw this in Ariel Bissett's end of year video where she talks about her favorite books, and this one made the list. She talked so passionately about it that I literally bought it the second after that video ended. I don't run...or write, but I still found myself able to get something out of this book. Haruki Murakami's writing style flows so nicely, and reading this felt like a cool breeze on a hot day (kind of weird comparison but that's what I felt haha). However, I don't know why it is, but nonfiction just doesn't click with me as much. It takes a lot for me to really love a nonfiction book. I took some things away from this but I didn't quite love it.

I enjoyed it a lot! Short memoir-style collection of connected essays. Full of mindfulness and reflection. Excellent companion for the evening commute.Also, fantastic palette cleanser for those (like me) binge reading fantasy like there is no tomorrow ğŸ˜

Not really sure why I read this considering I donâ€™t run But I did enjoy it even so and if I was a runner I think I would have really liked it It IS inspiring , but not enough for me to start marathon training
Quiet and thoughtful memoir. I liked Murakami's ruminations about his training, his running philosophy and the bits abiut his life before writing and running.

Ma cosa ben diversa Ã¨ ascoltare la persona in carne ed ossa mentre ti parla della sua vita reale.Delle sue stranezze e della sua cura della fisicitÃ , del suo modo di porsi di fronte alla vita. L'impegno maniacale, le sfide solitarie, la propria asocialitÃ  e solitudine.
